title: ExaCraft: Dynamic Learning Context Adaptation for Personalized Educational Examples
summary: Learning is most effective when it's connected to relevant, relatable examples that resonate with learners on a personal level. However, existing educational AI tools don't focus on generating examples or adapting to learners' changing understanding, struggles, or growing skills. We've developed ExaCraft, an AI system that generates personalized examples by adapting to the learner's dynamic context. Through the Google Gemini AI and Python Flask API, accessible via a Chrome extension, ExaCraft combines user-defined profiles (including location, education, profession, and complexity preferences) with real-time analysis of learner behavior. This ensures examples are both culturally relevant and tailored to individual learning needs. The system's core innovation is its ability to adapt to five key aspects of the learning context: indicators of struggle, mastery patterns, topic progression history, session boundaries, and learning progression signals. Our demonstration will show how ExaCraft's examples evolve from basic concepts to advanced technical implementations, responding to topic repetition, regeneration requests, and topic progression patterns in different use cases.

AI.tldr: ExaCraft is an AI system that generates culturally relevant, personalized learning examples that adapt in real-time to a learner’s evolving context and behavior.
AI.motivation: Traditional educational AI tools rarely generate tailored examples or adapt as learners’ understanding, struggles, and skills change. There is a need for systems that provide context-aware, personally meaningful examples to support deeper, more effective learning.
AI.method: ExaCraft uses Google Gemini AI integrated with a Python Flask API and delivered via a Chrome extension. It combines static user profile data (location, education, profession, complexity preferences) with dynamic signals from real-time learner behavior. The system models five aspects of learning context—struggle indicators, mastery patterns, topic progression history, session boundaries, and learning progression signals—to continuously adapt the examples it generates.
AI.result: The system can generate examples that evolve from simple to advanced, change in response to topic repetition or regeneration requests, and align with observed learning patterns across different use cases. The demo shows ExaCraft successfully tailoring and updating examples based on these contextual signals.
AI.conclusion: ExaCraft demonstrates that AI-driven, context-aware example generation is feasible and can produce personalized, culturally relevant examples that track and respond to a learner’s ongoing progress, offering a promising direction for more adaptive and effective educational tools.

title: Suzume-chan: Your Personal Navigator as an Embodied Information Hub
comment: 3 pages, 1 figure, This study will demonstrate at WISS 2025
summary: Access to expert knowledge often requires real-time human communication. Digital tools improve access to information but rarely create the sense of connection needed for deep understanding. This study addresses this issue using Social Presence Theory, which explains how a feeling of "being together" enhances communication. An "Embodied Information Hub" is proposed as a new way to share knowledge through physical and conversational interaction. The prototype, Suzume-chan, is a small, soft AI agent running locally with a language model and retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). It learns from spoken explanations and responds through dialogue, reducing psychological distance and making knowledge sharing warmer and more human-centered.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a tangible, conversational AI agent (“Embodied Information Hub”) that uses local LLM + RAG to learn from spoken explanations and provide warm, human-like knowledge sharing based on Social Presence Theory.
AI.motivation: Traditional digital tools provide information efficiently but fail to recreate the sense of interpersonal connection required for deep understanding and effective expert–novice knowledge transfer. The authors are motivated by the gap between cold, impersonal interfaces and the rich, relational feel of real-time human communication, and they use Social Presence Theory to frame the need for designs that evoke a feeling of “being together.”
AI.method: They design and prototype an “Embodied Information Hub” named Suzume-chan: a small, soft, physically present AI agent. Technically it runs a local language model combined with retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). Interaction is primarily spoken: experts verbally explain knowledge to the agent, which stores and organizes it, and later engages in dialogic retrieval with users. The design emphasizes physical form, softness, and conversational behavior to increase social presence and reduce psychological distance.
AI.result: The prototype demonstrates that expert knowledge can be captured via spoken explanations and later accessed through natural dialogue, all on a local device using LLM + RAG. Initial observations (implied by the abstract) suggest users experience the interaction as warmer and more human-centered compared to standard digital interfaces, indicating increased social presence and reduced psychological distance.
AI.conclusion: Embodied, socially present AI agents that blend physical form with conversational AI are a promising approach for more human-centered knowledge sharing. By leveraging Social Presence Theory and technologies like local LLMs and RAG, such systems can make accessing expert knowledge feel more like interacting with a person than a database, potentially improving comprehension, engagement, and comfort in expert–novice communication.

title: Exploring Health Misinformation Detection with Multi-Agent Debate
summary: Fact-checking health-related claims has become increasingly critical as misinformation proliferates online. Effective verification requires both the retrieval of high-quality evidence and rigorous reasoning processes. In this paper, we propose a two-stage framework for health misinformation detection: Agreement Score Prediction followed by Multi-Agent Debate. In the first stage, we employ large language models (LLMs) to independently evaluate retrieved articles and compute an aggregated agreement score that reflects the overall evidence stance. When this score indicates insufficient consensus-falling below a predefined threshold-the system proceeds to a second stage. Multiple agents engage in structured debate to synthesize conflicting evidence and generate well-reasoned verdicts with explicit justifications. Experimental results demonstrate that our two-stage approach achieves superior performance compared to baseline methods, highlighting the value of combining automated scoring with collaborative reasoning for complex verification tasks.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a two-stage framework for detecting health misinformation that first computes an evidence agreement score with LLMs and then triggers a multi-agent debate when evidence is conflicting, resulting in better verification performance.
AI.motivation: Health misinformation is widespread online, and accurate fact-checking requires not only retrieving relevant evidence but also reasoning over potentially conflicting sources. Existing methods often struggle either with evidence aggregation or complex reasoning, especially when evidence does not clearly agree.
AI.method: The method is a two-stage framework. Stage 1: Retrieved articles are independently assessed by large language models, which output stances that are aggregated into an overall agreement score indicating how much the evidence supports or refutes a claim. If this score is above a threshold, the system can make a decision directly. If the score is below a predefined threshold (indicating low consensus), Stage 2 is triggered: multiple LLM-based agents participate in a structured debate over the evidence, synthesizing conflicting viewpoints and jointly producing a final verdict with explicit justification.
AI.result: Experiments show that this two-stage approach outperforms baseline health misinformation detection methods across evaluation metrics, suggesting that combining automated agreement scoring with a debate mechanism leads to more accurate verification, particularly in complex or ambiguous cases.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating an agreement-scoring stage followed by a multi-agent debate improves health misinformation detection by better handling conflicting or low-consensus evidence and yielding more accurate and explainable verification outcomes.

title: Echo-CoPilot: A Multi-View, Multi-Task Agent for Echocardiography Interpretation and Reporting
summary: Echocardiography is central to contemporary cardiovascular care, but full-study interpretation remains a cognitively demanding, multi-view task that is still performed manually. While recent foundation models for echocardiography can achieve strong performance on individual perceptual subtasks such as view classification, segmentation, or disease prediction, they typically operate in isolation and do not provide a unified, clinically coherent assessment. In this work, we introduce Echo-CoPilot, a multi-view, multi-task agent that uses a large language model to orchestrate a suite of specialized echocardiography tools. Within a ReAct-style loop, the agent decomposes clinician queries, invokes tools for view recognition, cardiac structure segmentation, measurement and disease prediction, and report synthesis, and integrates their outputs into guideline-aware answers and narrative summaries. We evaluate Echo-CoPilot on the public MIMIC-EchoQA benchmark, where it achieves an accuracy of 50.8\%, outperforming both general-purpose and biomedical video vision-language models. Qualitative analyses further show that the agent leverages quantitative measurements and physiologic context to resolve challenging cases near clinical decision thresholds, such as borderline left ventricular hypertrophy or pericardial effusion severity. The code will be released upon acceptance of the paper.

AI.tldr: Echo-CoPilot is an LLM-orchestrated, multi-view, multi-task agent that coordinates specialized echocardiography tools to answer clinician queries and generate coherent echo reports, outperforming prior echo vision-language models on a public benchmark.
AI.motivation: Although echocardiography is central in cardiovascular care, full-study interpretation is complex, multi-view, and still done manually. Existing foundation models handle only narrow subtasks (view classification, segmentation, or disease prediction) in isolation, so they cannot deliver an end-to-end, clinically coherent assessment or respond flexibly to clinician queries.
AI.method: The authors build Echo-CoPilot, an agentic system that uses a large language model in a ReAct-style loop to plan and coordinate multiple specialized echo tools. Given a clinician query, the LLM decomposes it into subtasks and calls tools for view recognition, cardiac structure segmentation, quantitative measurements, disease prediction, and report generation. It then integrates these outputs, using guideline knowledge, into final answers and narrative summaries that reflect clinical reasoning across views and tasks.
AI.result: On the MIMIC-EchoQA benchmark, Echo-CoPilot achieves 50.8% accuracy, surpassing both general-purpose and biomedical video vision-language baselines. Qualitatively, the system shows that it can exploit numerical measurements and physiologic context to handle borderline cases near guideline thresholds, such as mild versus moderate left ventricular hypertrophy and gradations of pericardial effusion.
AI.conclusion: Coordinating specialized echocardiography models through an LLM-based agent yields more clinically coherent multi-view interpretations than standalone models, improving performance on echo question answering and enabling guideline-aware, narrative reporting. This suggests that agentic orchestration is a promising path toward practical AI copilots for echo reading and broader medical imaging workflows.

title: What Kind of Reasoning (if any) is an LLM actually doing? On the Stochastic Nature and Abductive Appearance of Large Language Models
summary: This article looks at how reasoning works in current Large Language Models (LLMs) that function using the token-completion method. It examines their stochastic nature and their similarity to human abductive reasoning. The argument is that these LLMs create text based on learned patterns rather than performing actual abductive reasoning. When their output seems abductive, this is largely because they are trained on human-generated texts that include reasoning structures. Examples are used to show how LLMs can produce plausible ideas, mimic commonsense reasoning, and give explanatory answers without being grounded in truth, semantics, verification, or understanding, and without performing any real abductive reasoning. This dual nature, where the models have a stochastic base but appear abductive in use, has important consequences for how LLMs are evaluated and applied. They can assist with generating ideas and supporting human thinking, but their outputs must be critically assessed because they cannot identify truth or verify their explanations. The article concludes by addressing five objections to these points, noting some limitations in the analysis, and offering an overall evaluation.

AI.tldr: The paper argues that current token-based LLMs only simulate abductive reasoning through pattern completion on human texts, rather than performing genuine reasoning or truth-tracking, and that their outputs must therefore be critically evaluated.
AI.motivation: To clarify what kind of 'reasoning' current LLMs actually perform, especially in relation to abductive reasoning, and to prevent over-attributing understanding, semantics, or truth-tracking abilities to these models in research and applications.
AI.method: Conceptual and analytical investigation: the author analyzes the stochastic token-completion mechanism of LLMs, compares it with philosophical accounts of abductive reasoning, and illustrates the argument with examples of LLM outputs that appear explanatory or commonsense but are ultimately pattern-based and ungrounded.
AI.result: The analysis shows that LLMs generate outputs that can look like abductive inferences and commonsense explanations, but these arise from statistical pattern matching over training data rather than from processes that track truth, semantics, or verification. The paper identifies a mismatch between the models’ stochastic implementation and their seemingly rational behavior.
AI.conclusion: LLMs should be understood as powerful tools for generating ideas and assisting human reasoning, not as agents that themselves perform genuine abductive reasoning or truth evaluation. Their apparent reasoning capacities are derivative of human-authored training data, and their outputs need careful human scrutiny. The paper answers several objections, acknowledges limits of its analysis, and offers a cautious overall assessment of LLM capabilities and appropriate uses.

title: Generate-Then-Validate: A Novel Question Generation Approach Using Small Language Models
comment: Accepted as a full research paper for the 16th International Conference on Learning Analytics and Knowledge (LAK'26)
summary: We explore the use of small language models (SLMs) for automatic question generation as a complement to the prevalent use of their large counterparts in learning analytics research. We present a novel question generation pipeline that leverages both the text generation and the probabilistic reasoning abilities of SLMs to generate high-quality questions. Adopting a "generate-then-validate" strategy, our pipeline first performs expansive generation to create an abundance of candidate questions and refine them through selective validation based on novel probabilistic reasoning. We conducted two evaluation studies, one with seven human experts and the other with a large language model (LLM), to assess the quality of the generated questions. Most judges (humans or LLMs) agreed that the generated questions had clear answers and generally aligned well with the intended learning objectives. Our findings suggest that an SLM can effectively generate high-quality questions when guided by a well-designed pipeline that leverages its strengths.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a pipeline that uses small language models (SLMs) with a generate-then-validate strategy to automatically create high-quality educational questions, showing SLMs can work well when carefully guided.
AI.motivation: Most research on automatic question generation for learning analytics focuses on large language models, which are resource-intensive and not always practical. The authors aim to investigate whether smaller, more efficient models can still generate pedagogically valuable questions, reducing computational cost while maintaining quality.
AI.method: The authors design a novel question generation pipeline that exploits both text generation and probabilistic reasoning capabilities of SLMs. The pipeline works in two stages: (1) expansive generation, where the SLM produces many candidate questions; and (2) selective validation, where candidates are screened and refined using a probabilistic reasoning mechanism that assesses factors such as answer clarity and alignment with learning objectives. They then conduct two evaluation studies—one involving seven human experts, and another using a large language model as an automatic evaluator—to judge question quality.
AI.result: Both human experts and the LLM evaluator largely agreed that the questions generated by the SLM-based pipeline had clear, well-defined answers and generally matched the targeted learning objectives. This indicates that the generated questions are of high quality despite being produced by a small model.
AI.conclusion: With an appropriate generate-then-validate pipeline that leverages probabilistic reasoning, small language models can produce high-quality educational questions comparable to those typically expected from larger models. This opens the door to more resource-efficient, scalable question generation tools for learning analytics and educational applications.

title: Exploring LLMs for Scientific Information Extraction Using The SciEx Framework
summary: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly touted as powerful tools for automating scientific information extraction. However, existing methods and tools often struggle with the realities of scientific literature: long-context documents, multi-modal content, and reconciling varied and inconsistent fine-grained information across multiple publications into standardized formats. These challenges are further compounded when the desired data schema or extraction ontology changes rapidly, making it difficult to re-architect or fine-tune existing systems. We present SciEx, a modular and composable framework that decouples key components including PDF parsing, multi-modal retrieval, extraction, and aggregation. This design streamlines on-demand data extraction while enabling extensibility and flexible integration of new models, prompting strategies, and reasoning mechanisms. We evaluate SciEx on datasets spanning three scientific topics for its ability to extract fine-grained information accurately and consistently. Our findings provide practical insights into both the strengths and limitations of current LLM-based pipelines.

AI.tldr: SciEx is a modular framework that uses LLMs to extract fine-grained scientific information from complex, long, and multimodal literature.
AI.motivation: Existing LLM-based scientific extraction tools struggle with long documents, multimodal content (text, tables, figures), inconsistent information across multiple papers, and rapidly changing extraction schemas or ontologies. There is a need for a flexible, easily extensible system that can robustly extract structured data from scientific literature under these constraints.
AI.method: The authors design SciEx as a modular and composable pipeline that separates PDF parsing, multimodal retrieval, information extraction, and aggregation. This architecture allows plug-and-play integration of different models, prompts, and reasoning techniques for each stage, supporting on-demand extraction and easy adaptation to new schemas or tools.
AI.result: SciEx is evaluated on datasets from three different scientific domains, focusing on its ability to extract fine-grained information consistently and accurately. The experiments show how well SciEx performs and highlight both where it succeeds and where it struggles as an LLM-based extraction pipeline.
AI.conclusion: SciEx provides a flexible, modular framework that improves the practicality of LLM-based scientific information extraction, particularly for long-context, multimodal, and cross-document scenarios, while also revealing current limitations and guiding future improvements in such pipelines.

title: Workflow is All You Need: Escaping the "Statistical Smoothing Trap" via High-Entropy Information Foraging and Adversarial Pacing
comment: 22 pages, 8 figures. Includes an ecological validity blind test where the Agentic Workflow achieved a 25% acceptance rate in top-tier media, decisively outperforming the SOTA Zero-shot baseline (0%). Features the DNFO-v5 ontology
summary: Central to long-form text generation in vertical domains is the "impossible trinity" confronting current large language models (LLMs): the simultaneous achievement of low hallucination, deep logical coherence, and personalized expression. This study establishes that this bottleneck arises from existing generative paradigms succumbing to the Statistical Smoothing Trap, a phenomenon that overlooks the high-entropy information acquisition and structured cognitive processes integral to expert-level writing. To address this limitation, we propose the DeepNews Framework, an agentic workflow that explicitly models the implicit cognitive processes of seasoned financial journalists. The framework integrates three core modules: first, a dual-granularity retrieval mechanism grounded in information foraging theory, which enforces a 10:1 saturated information input ratio to mitigate hallucinatory outputs; second, schema-guided strategic planning, a process leveraging domain expert knowledge bases (narrative schemas) and Atomic Blocks to forge a robust logical skeleton; third, adversarial constraint prompting, a technique deploying tactics including Rhythm Break and Logic Fog to disrupt the probabilistic smoothness inherent in model-generated text. Experiments delineate a salient Knowledge Cliff in deep financial reporting: content truthfulness collapses when retrieved context falls below 15,000 characters, while a high-redundancy input exceeding 30,000 characters stabilizes the Hallucination-Free Rate (HFR) above 85%. In an ecological validity blind test conducted with a top-tier Chinese technology media outlet, the DeepNews system--built on a previous-generation model (DeepSeek-V3-0324)-achieved a 25% submission acceptance rate, significantly outperforming the 0% acceptance rate of zero-shot generation by a state-of-the-art (SOTA) model (GPT-5).

AI.tldr: The paper proposes DeepNews, an agentic framework to overcome the “impossible trinity” of low hallucination, deep logical coherence, and personalized style in long-form financial text generation by LLMs.
AI.motivation: Current LLMs in vertical, long-form writing (like financial journalism) struggle to simultaneously avoid hallucinations, maintain strong logical structure, and preserve a distinctive, human-like narrative style. The authors argue this is due to the Statistical Smoothing Trap, where models rely on probabilistic smoothness rather than the high-entropy, structured reasoning processes used by expert writers.
AI.method: They design DeepNews, which emulates expert financial journalists via: (1) a dual-granularity retrieval system based on information foraging theory that enforces a high (10:1) ratio of factual input to generated output; (2) schema-guided strategic planning that uses narrative schemas and Atomic Blocks to build a solid logical outline before writing; and (3) adversarial constraint prompting (e.g., Rhythm Break, Logic Fog) to deliberately disrupt overly smooth, generic text patterns and push the model into more analytic, specific generation.
AI.result: Experiments reveal a “Knowledge Cliff”: if retrieved context is under 15,000 characters, factual accuracy in deep financial reporting degrades sharply, while above 30,000 characters and with redundancy, the Hallucination-Free Rate exceeds 85%. In a blind test with a major Chinese tech media outlet, DeepNews (on an older model, DeepSeek-V3-0324) attained a 25% article acceptance rate, whereas zero-shot generation using a SOTA model (GPT-5) yielded 0% acceptance.
AI.conclusion: Explicitly modeling expert-like cognition via retrieval, schema-based planning, and adversarial prompting can significantly improve long-form, domain-specific generation. DeepNews mitigates hallucinations while preserving logical depth and personalized style, and can outperform more powerful but naively used LLMs in real editorial settings.

title: DynaMate: An Autonomous Agent for Protein-Ligand Molecular Dynamics Simulations
summary: Force field-based molecular dynamics (MD) simulations are indispensable for probing the structure, dynamics, and functions of biomolecular systems, including proteins and protein-ligand complexes. Despite their broad utility in drug discovery and protein engineering, the technical complexity of MD setup, encompassing parameterization, input preparation, and software configuration, remains a major barrier for widespread and efficient usage. Agentic LLMs have demonstrated their capacity to autonomously execute multi-step scientific processes, and to date, they have not successfully been used to automate protein-ligand MD workflows. Here, we present DynaMate, a modular multi-agent framework that autonomously designs and executes complete MD workflows for both protein and protein-ligand systems, and offers free energy binding affinity calculations with the MM/PB(GB)SA method. The framework integrates dynamic tool use, web search, PaperQA, and a self-correcting behavior. DynaMate comprises three specialized modules, interacting to plan the experiment, perform the simulation, and analyze the results. We evaluated its performance across twelve benchmark systems of varying complexity, assessing success rate, efficiency, and adaptability. DynaMate reliably performed full MD simulations, corrected runtime errors through iterative reasoning, and produced meaningful analyses of protein-ligand interactions. This automated framework paves the way toward standardized, scalable, and time-efficient molecular modeling pipelines for future biomolecular and drug design applications.

AI.tldr: DynaMate is a multi-agent LLM framework that autonomously sets up, runs, and analyzes protein and protein-ligand molecular dynamics simulations, including binding free energy calculations.
AI.motivation: Molecular dynamics simulations are powerful for studying biomolecular structure and function but remain technically challenging to set up due to complex parameterization, input preparation, and software configuration. This complexity limits their widespread and efficient use in drug discovery and protein engineering. Recent advances in agentic LLMs show potential for automating multi-step scientific workflows, but they have not yet been successfully applied to fully automate protein-ligand MD pipelines.
AI.method: The authors design DynaMate, a modular, multi-agent framework powered by LLMs. It uses dynamic tool calling, web search, PaperQA, and self-correcting behavior to autonomously plan, execute, and analyze MD simulations. The system is divided into three specialized modules: one for experimental planning (workflow design and system setup), one for running the simulations (MD execution and error handling), and one for analyzing results (including MM/PB(GB)SA binding free energy calculations and interaction analysis). The framework iteratively reasons about and corrects errors during runtime.
AI.result: On a benchmark of twelve protein and protein-ligand systems with varying complexity, DynaMate successfully executed complete MD workflows. It achieved a high success rate in running full simulations, demonstrated the ability to recover from runtime errors via iterative reasoning and self-correction, and produced informative analyses of protein-ligand interactions and binding affinities.
AI.conclusion: DynaMate shows that agentic LLMs can autonomously manage end-to-end MD simulations for biomolecular systems, from design and setup to execution and analysis. This approach can standardize, scale, and accelerate molecular modeling workflows, with promising implications for biomolecular research and drug discovery pipelines.

title: PARAN: Persona-Augmented Review ANswering system on Food Delivery Review Dataset
summary: Personalized review response generation presents a significant challenge in domains where user information is limited, such as food delivery platforms. While large language models (LLMs) offer powerful text generation capabilities, they often produce generic responses when lacking contextual user data, reducing engagement and effectiveness. In this work, we propose a two-stage prompting framework that infers both explicit (e.g., user-stated preferences) and implicit (e.g., demographic or stylistic cues) personas directly from short review texts. These inferred persona attributes are then incorporated into the response generation prompt to produce user-tailored replies. To encourage diverse yet faithful generations, we adjust decoding temperature during inference. We evaluate our method using a real-world dataset collected from a Korean food delivery app, and assess its impact on precision, diversity, and semantic consistency. Our findings highlight the effectiveness of persona-augmented prompting in enhancing the relevance and personalization of automated responses without requiring model fine-tuning.

AI.tldr: They infer a user persona from each short review, then feed that persona into an LLM prompt to generate more personalized review replies, improving relevance and diversity without fine-tuning.
AI.motivation: Food delivery and similar platforms want engaging, personalized responses to user reviews, but they often lack rich user profiles. Off‑the‑shelf LLMs tend to respond in generic ways when they only see the raw review text, which hurts user engagement and doesn’t fully exploit LLM capabilities. The authors aim to bridge this gap by extracting more nuanced user characteristics directly from the review itself, so that responses can be tailored without needing explicit user data or costly model fine‑tuning.
AI.method: They design a two‑stage prompting framework for LLMs. In stage one, the model is prompted to infer a persona from each review, including explicit attributes (like directly stated preferences) and implicit ones (such as demographic hints or stylistic traits) derived from short texts alone. In stage two, these inferred persona attributes are injected into a response‑generation prompt, guiding the LLM to produce a reply tailored to that persona. To balance creativity and faithfulness, they tune the decoding temperature during inference. They then evaluate on a real‑world dataset from a Korean food delivery app, measuring precision, diversity, and semantic consistency of responses.
AI.result: On the Korean food delivery review dataset, persona‑augmented prompting yields responses that are more relevant to the user’s inferred preferences and style, more diverse, and still semantically consistent with the original review compared with baseline, more generic LLM responses. This demonstrates that structured persona inference plus controlled decoding can improve personalization without additional training data or fine‑tuning.
AI.conclusion: Inferring explicit and implicit user personas directly from short reviews and feeding these personas back into LLM prompts is an effective way to personalize automated review responses when user data is sparse. The proposed two‑stage prompting plus temperature tuning produces more tailored, diverse, and faithful replies on a real food‑delivery platform dataset, showing that prompting alone can substantially enhance LLM‑based customer interaction systems without modifying model weights.

title: SimWorld-Robotics: Synthesizing Photorealistic and Dynamic Urban Environments for Multimodal Robot Navigation and Collaboration
summary: Recent advances in foundation models have shown promising results in developing generalist robotics that can perform diverse tasks in open-ended scenarios given multimodal inputs. However, current work has been mainly focused on indoor, household scenarios. In this work, we present SimWorld-Robotics~(SWR), a simulation platform for embodied AI in large-scale, photorealistic urban environments. Built on Unreal Engine 5, SWR procedurally generates unlimited photorealistic urban scenes populated with dynamic elements such as pedestrians and traffic systems, surpassing prior urban simulations in realism, complexity, and scalability. It also supports multi-robot control and communication. With these key features, we build two challenging robot benchmarks: (1) a multimodal instruction-following task, where a robot must follow vision-language navigation instructions to reach a destination in the presence of pedestrians and traffic; and (2) a multi-agent search task, where two robots must communicate to cooperatively locate and meet each other. Unlike existing benchmarks, these two new benchmarks comprehensively evaluate a wide range of critical robot capacities in realistic scenarios, including (1) multimodal instructions grounding, (2) 3D spatial reasoning in large environments, (3) safe, long-range navigation with people and traffic, (4) multi-robot collaboration, and (5) grounded communication. Our experimental results demonstrate that state-of-the-art models, including vision-language models (VLMs), struggle with our tasks, lacking robust perception, reasoning, and planning abilities necessary for urban environments.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces SimWorld-Robotics, a highly realistic, large-scale urban simulation platform for embodied AI, and shows that current state-of-the-art models perform poorly on its challenging benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Existing foundation-model-based generalist robots are mostly designed and evaluated in constrained indoor, household environments, which do not capture the complexity, dynamics, and safety challenges of real-world urban settings. There is a need for a scalable, photorealistic, and dynamic urban simulator to develop and rigorously benchmark embodied AI systems, especially those using multimodal foundation models, on tasks closer to real-world outdoor robotics.
AI.method: The authors build SimWorld-Robotics (SWR) on Unreal Engine 5, enabling procedural generation of unlimited, photorealistic, large-scale urban scenes with dynamic elements like pedestrians and traffic, and supporting multi-robot control and communication. On top of this platform, they design two benchmarks: (1) a multimodal instruction-following task where a robot navigates through dynamic urban environments using vision-language instructions; (2) a multi-agent search task where two robots must coordinate via communication to find and meet each other. They then evaluate state-of-the-art models, including vision-language models, on these tasks to assess capabilities such as multimodal grounding, spatial reasoning, safe navigation, collaboration, and grounded communication.
AI.result: SimWorld-Robotics is able to generate realistic, complex, and scalable urban environments with dynamic entities and multi-robot support, exceeding prior urban simulators in these aspects. The two benchmarks successfully stress-test multiple key capabilities of embodied AI in urban settings. When evaluated on these benchmarks, current state-of-the-art models, including advanced vision-language models, perform poorly, revealing significant deficiencies in perception, reasoning, planning, and interaction required for robust urban robotics.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that SimWorld-Robotics provides a more realistic and challenging testbed for embodied AI in urban environments than existing simulators and benchmarks. The poor performance of current state-of-the-art models on the proposed benchmarks highlights a substantial gap between present capabilities and what is needed for safe and effective urban robotics. This underscores the need for future research on stronger perception, spatial reasoning, planning, collaboration, and communication in complex real-world-like settings, and positions SWR as a valuable platform for such progress.

title: Parallel Decoder Transformer: Model-Internal Parallel Decoding with Speculative Invariance via Note Conditioning
summary:
Autoregressive decoding in Large Language Models (LLMs) is inherently sequential, creating a latency bottleneck that scales linearly with output length. While ``Decomposition-and-Fill'' methods like Skeleton-of-Thought attempt to parallelize generation via external orchestration, they suffer from \textit{coherence drift} due to the lack of cross-stream communication. In this work, we introduce the \textbf{Parallel Decoder Transformer (PDT)}, a parameter-efficient architecture that embeds coordination primitives directly into the inference process of a frozen pre-trained model.
  Instead of retraining the base model, PDT injects lightweight \textit{Speculative Note Conditioning (SNC)} adapters that allow parallel decoding streams to synchronize via a shared, dynamic latent space. We formulate coordination as a \textit{speculative consensus} problem, where sibling streams broadcast semantic ``notes'' to a global bus, gated by a learned verification head. We validate our approach on a 50,000-step curriculum using a frozen 20B-parameter backbone. Our results demonstrate that PDT achieves effective self-correction, reaching \textbf{77.8\% precision} in coverage prediction and recovering approximate serial semantics without modifying the trunk weights. This establishes PDT as a scalable, efficient alternative to full model fine-tuning for structured parallel generation.

AI.tldr: They introduce Parallel Decoder Transformer (PDT), which enables multiple decoding streams of an LLM to run in parallel while staying coherent via a shared latent “note” space, reducing latency without retraining the base model.
AI.motivation: Autoregressive decoding is sequential and slow, and existing decomposition-and-fill parallelization methods cause coherence drift because parallel branches cannot communicate effectively. They want a way to parallelize decoding while maintaining coherence, without expensive full-model retraining.
AI.method: They keep a large frozen 20B LLM backbone and add lightweight Speculative Note Conditioning (SNC) adapter modules. During decoding, multiple parallel streams generate tokens while writing and reading semantic “notes” on a shared latent bus. A learned verification head gates which notes are accepted, framing coordination as a speculative consensus problem. These SNC adapters are trained over a 50,000-step curriculum while trunk weights stay fixed.
AI.result: On a frozen 20B backbone, PDT achieves 77.8% precision in predicting which content should be covered (coverage prediction) and reconstructs semantics close to standard serial decoding, despite parallelization and no trunk weight updates.
AI.conclusion: Embedding SNC adapters into the decoder allows parallel decoding streams to self-correct and coordinate via a shared latent space, mitigating coherence drift. PDT thus offers a parameter-efficient, scalable alternative to full fine-tuning for structured parallel generation in LLMs.

title: AutoMedic: An Automated Evaluation Framework for Clinical Conversational Agents with Medical Dataset Grounding
summary: Evaluating large language models (LLMs) has recently emerged as a critical issue for safe and trustworthy application of LLMs in the medical domain. Although a variety of static medical question-answering (QA) benchmarks have been proposed, many aspects remain underexplored, such as the effectiveness of LLMs in generating responses in dynamic, interactive clinical multi-turn conversation situations and the identification of multi-faceted evaluation strategies beyond simple accuracy. However, formally evaluating a dynamic, interactive clinical situation is hindered by its vast combinatorial space of possible patient states and interaction trajectories, making it difficult to standardize and quantitatively measure such scenarios. Here, we introduce AutoMedic, a multi-agent simulation framework that enables automated evaluation of LLMs as clinical conversational agents. AutoMedic transforms off-the-shelf static QA datasets into virtual patient profiles, enabling realistic and clinically grounded multi-turn clinical dialogues between LLM agents. The performance of various clinical conversational agents is then assessed based on our CARE metric, which provides a multi-faceted evaluation standard of clinical conversational accuracy, efficiency/strategy, empathy, and robustness. Our findings, validated by human experts, demonstrate the validity of AutoMedic as an automated evaluation framework for clinical conversational agents, offering practical guidelines for the effective development of LLMs in conversational medical applications.

AI.tldr: The paper presents AutoMedic, a multi-agent simulation framework to automatically evaluate large language models as clinical conversational agents using dynamic, multi-turn dialogues derived from static QA datasets and a multi-dimensional CARE metric.
AI.motivation: Existing medical LLM evaluation largely relies on static QA benchmarks that do not capture dynamic, interactive, multi-turn clinical conversations or multi-faceted qualities (e.g., empathy, strategy, robustness). Evaluating such realistic clinical interactions is challenging due to the large combinatorial space of patient states and dialogue trajectories, making standardized, quantitative assessment difficult.
AI.method: The authors build AutoMedic, a multi-agent simulation framework that converts existing static medical QA datasets into virtual patient profiles. These profiles are used to simulate realistic, clinically grounded, multi-turn dialogues between LLM-based clinical agents and virtual patients. The framework then evaluates agents with the CARE metric, which measures accuracy, efficiency/strategy in information gathering and decision-making, expressed empathy, and robustness across diverse conversational scenarios. Human experts are used to validate the framework’s assessments.
AI.result: Using AutoMedic, the authors evaluate various LLM-based clinical conversational agents and obtain quantitative scores along the CARE dimensions. The simulated evaluations show strong agreement with human expert judgments, indicating that AutoMedic’s automated metrics reliably reflect clinical conversational quality across accuracy, strategy, empathy, and robustness.
AI.conclusion: AutoMedic is a valid and practical automated evaluation framework for clinical conversational LLMs. By turning static QA data into dynamic multi-turn simulations and using the CARE metric for multi-dimensional assessment, it offers a scalable, standardized way to benchmark and guide the development of safer, more effective medical conversational agents.

title: Mind the Gap! Pathways Towards Unifying AI Safety and Ethics Research
summary:
While much research in artificial intelligence (AI) has focused on scaling capabilities, the accelerating pace of development makes countervailing work on producing harmless, "aligned" systems increasingly urgent. Yet research on alignment has diverged along two largely parallel tracks: safety--centered on scaled intelligence, deceptive or scheming behaviors, and existential risk--and ethics--focused on present harms, the reproduction of social bias, and flaws in production pipelines. Although both communities warn of insufficient investment in alignment, they disagree on what alignment means or ought to mean. As a result, their efforts have evolved in relative isolation, shaped by distinct methodologies, institutional homes, and disciplinary genealogies.
  We present a large-scale, quantitative study showing the structural split between AI safety and AI ethics. Using a bibliometric and co-authorship network analysis of 6,442 papers from twelve major ML and NLP conferences (2020-2025), we find that over 80% of collaborations occur within either the safety or ethics communities, and cross-field connectivity is highly concentrated: roughly 5% of papers account for more than 85% of bridging links. Removing a small number of these brokers sharply increases segregation, indicating that cross-disciplinary exchange depends on a handful of actors rather than broad, distributed collaboration. These results show that the safety-ethics divide is not only conceptual but institutional, with implications for research agendas, policy, and venues. We argue that integrating technical safety work with normative ethics--via shared benchmarks, cross-institutional venues, and mixed-method methodologies--is essential for building AI systems that are both robust and just.

AI.tldr: The paper quantitatively demonstrates a strong structural divide between AI safety and AI ethics research communities using large-scale bibliometric and co-authorship analysis, and argues for institutional and methodological integration to build AI systems that are both robust and just.
AI.motivation: AI capabilities are rapidly scaling, increasing the urgency of alignment research. However, alignment work is split into two parallel and weakly connected tracks: AI safety (focused on long-term, systemic, and existential risks) and AI ethics (focused on current harms, bias, and governance failures). Despite shared concerns about insufficient alignment, these communities define and pursue alignment differently and are institutionally separated. The paper is motivated by the need to move beyond anecdotal claims and qualitatively perceived divides by providing a large-scale, quantitative analysis of how structurally fragmented these fields actually are, and what that implies for the future of AI alignment research and policy.
AI.method: The authors conduct a bibliometric and co-authorship network analysis on 6,442 papers drawn from twelve major machine learning (ML) and natural language processing (NLP) conferences published between 2020 and 2025. They classify papers into AI safety or AI ethics categories, then construct collaboration networks based on co-authorship relationships. They measure intra- vs. inter-community collaborations, analyze the distribution of “bridging” papers and authors that connect the two communities, and run counterfactual removal experiments to see how deleting these brokers affects overall network segregation and connectivity. This reveals how structurally dependent cross-field exchange is on a small subset of actors and papers.
AI.result: The analysis shows a clear structural divide: more than 80% of collaborations occur exclusively within either the AI safety or AI ethics community rather than between them. Cross-field connectivity is highly skewed: about 5% of the papers generate more than 85% of all bridging links between the two communities. When these key “broker” papers and their associated authors are removed from the collaboration network, measures of segregation increase sharply, indicating that most cross-community exchange is funneled through a small, non-representative set of actors instead of being broadly distributed across the field. This empirically confirms that the safety–ethics split is entrenched not only in concepts and discourse but also in institutional and collaboration structures.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that the divide between AI safety and AI ethics is both conceptual and institutional, and that current patterns of collaboration are fragile because they depend heavily on a small number of brokers. This structural separation has significant consequences for research agendas, policy design, and the shape of AI conferences and institutions. To develop AI systems that are at once robust (technically safe, reliable, and non-deceptive) and just (socially fair, non-exploitative, and accountable), the authors argue that technical safety research must be systematically integrated with normative ethics. They recommend fostering shared benchmarks, building cross-institutional and cross-disciplinary venues, and promoting mixed-method methodologies that combine technical, empirical, and normative analysis, so that alignment work is better coordinated and more comprehensive.

title: Multilingual VLM Training: Adapting an English-Trained VLM to French
summary: Artificial intelligence has made great progress in recent years, particularly in the development of Vision--Language Models (VLMs) that understand both visual and textual data. However, these advancements remain largely limited to English, reducing their accessibility for non--English speakers. It is essential to extend these capabilities to a broader range of languages. This paper explores the challenges of adapting an English-trained VLM to different languages. To this end, we will explore and compare different methods for their performance and computational cost. We consider a translation-based pipeline, LoRA finetuning, and a two-stage finetuning strategy that separates vision adaptation from language adaptation. To evaluate these methods, we use a combination of standard multimodal benchmarks translated into the target language and manual assessments by native experts. The results reveal that dataset translation remains a major bottleneck in multilingual VLM performance, with data quality limiting the effectiveness of training and evaluation. These findings suggest that future efforts should focus on native-language dataset collection and improved translation strategies.

AI.tldr: The paper evaluates ways to adapt an English-trained vision–language model (VLM) to new languages and finds that translation quality of datasets is the main bottleneck, recommending more native-language data and better translation strategies.
AI.motivation: Most advanced vision–language models are trained and evaluated primarily in English, which limits their usefulness for speakers of other languages. To make these models more inclusive and broadly usable, it is necessary to understand how best to adapt English-trained VLMs to additional languages, balancing performance with computational cost. The paper is motivated by this gap and aims to systematically compare adaptation strategies and uncover key obstacles in multilingual VLM development.
AI.method: The paper investigates three adaptation strategies for English-trained VLMs: (1) a translation-based pipeline that translates data between English and the target language; (2) LoRA finetuning, a parameter-efficient finetuning technique applied to the VLM on target-language data; and (3) a two-stage finetuning approach that decouples vision and language adaptation, first adapting the visual component and then the language component. Performance is evaluated using standard multimodal benchmarks that have been translated into the target language and through manual evaluations by native-language experts.
AI.result: Across the evaluated methods, performance is strongly constrained by the quality of translated datasets. Even when adaptation techniques such as LoRA or two-stage finetuning are employed, noisy or low-quality translations limit both training effectiveness and reliability of benchmark evaluations. The comparison suggests that differences between adaptation strategies can be overshadowed by translation artifacts and dataset quality issues.
AI.conclusion: The study concludes that dataset translation is a critical bottleneck for multilingual VLMs. Improving translation quality and, more importantly, collecting native-language multimodal datasets are crucial for further progress. Future research should prioritize better translation pipelines and large-scale, high-quality native-language data rather than relying solely on adapting English-trained models via translated benchmarks.

title: Linear socio-demographic representations emerge in Large Language Models from indirect cues
summary: We investigate how LLMs encode sociodemographic attributes of human conversational partners inferred from indirect cues such as names and occupations. We show that LLMs develop linear representations of user demographics within activation space, wherein stereotypically associated attributes are encoded along interpretable geometric directions. We first probe residual streams across layers of four open transformer-based LLMs (Magistral 24B, Qwen3 14B, GPT-OSS 20B, OLMo2-1B) prompted with explicit demographic disclosure. We show that the same probes predict demographics from implicit cues: names activate census-aligned gender and race representations, while occupations trigger representations correlated with real-world workforce statistics. These linear representations allow us to explain demographic inferences implicitly formed by LLMs during conversation. We demonstrate that these implicit demographic representations actively shape downstream behavior, such as career recommendations. Our study further highlights that models that pass bias benchmark tests may still harbor and leverage implicit biases, with implications for fairness when applied at scale.

AI.tldr: The paper studies how large language models internally encode users’ sociodemographic attributes from indirect cues like names and occupations, finds linear, interpretable demographic directions in activation space, and shows these implicit encodings influence downstream behaviors such as recommendations despite bias benchmarks being passed.
AI.motivation: To understand whether and how LLMs infer and internally represent users’ sociodemographic attributes, even when only indirect cues are given, and to assess how these hidden representations affect model behavior and fairness beyond what standard bias benchmarks reveal.
AI.method: They probe residual stream activations across layers of four open-source transformer LLMs (Magistral 24B, Qwen3 14B, GPT-OSS 20B, OLMo2-1B). First, they prompt the models with explicit demographic disclosures to train linear probes that recover attributes from activations. Then they apply these probes to runs where demographics are only indirectly cued via names or occupations, and compare inferred attributes to external statistics (e.g., census gender/race data, workforce demographics). Finally, they relate these internal demographic representations to downstream behavioral differences, such as in career recommendation outputs.
AI.result: The models exhibit linear, low-dimensional demographic representations in their activation spaces, with interpretable geometric directions corresponding to stereotypical demographic attributes. Probes trained on explicit disclosures successfully predict demographics from implicit cues. Names elicit activation patterns that align with census-based gender and race distributions, and occupations produce representations correlated with real-world workforce demographic statistics. These internal demographic encodings systematically correlate with differences in downstream behaviors, such as which careers are recommended to different inferred demographic profiles, even when models appear to perform well on conventional bias benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: LLMs implicitly infer and encode users’ sociodemographic attributes along linear, interpretable directions in activation space based on indirect cues, and these hidden representations meaningfully shape downstream model behavior. Passing standard bias benchmarks does not guarantee that models are free of consequential implicit biases. This has important implications for fairness, transparency, and the design of mitigation strategies when deploying LLMs at scale, suggesting the need for techniques that can detect, interpret, and control such internal demographic encodings.

title: Confucius Code Agent: An Open-sourced AI Software Engineer at Industrial Scale
summary: Real-world AI software engineering demands coding agents that can reason over massive repositories, maintain durable memory across and within long sessions, and robustly coordinate complex toolchains at test time. Existing open-source coding agents provide transparency but frequently fall short when pushed to these industrial-scale workloads, while proprietary coding agents offer strong practical performance but limited extensibility, interpretability, and controllability. We present the Confucius Code Agent (CCA), an open-sourced AI software engineer that can operate at an industrial scale. CCA is built atop the Confucius SDK, an open-sourced agent development platform designed around three complementary perspectives: Agent Experience (AX), User Experience (UX), and Developer Experience (DX). The SDK introduces a unified orchestrator with hierarchical working memory for long-context reasoning, a persistent note-taking system for cross-session continual learning, and a modular extension module for robust tool use. Moreover, a meta-agent automates the synthesis, evaluation, and refinement of agent configurations through a build-test-improve loop, enabling rapid agent development on new tasks, environments, and tool stacks. Instantiated on Confucius SDK with these mechanisms, CCA delivers strong performance on real-world software engineering tasks. On SWE-Bench-Pro, CCA achieves a state-of-the-art Resolve@1 performance of 54.3%, substantially improving over prior coding agents. Together, the Confucius SDK and CCA provide a transparent, extensible, and reproducible foundation for AI agents, bridge gaps between research prototypes and production-grade systems, and support agent development and deployment at industrial scale.

AI.tldr: Confucius Code Agent (CCA) is an open-source, industrial-scale AI software engineer that achieves state-of-the-art results on SWE-Bench-Pro by combining hierarchical memory, persistent notes, and modular tools via the Confucius SDK.
AI.motivation: Real-world AI software engineering needs coding agents that can handle huge codebases, remember information across long sessions, and reliably orchestrate complex tools. Existing open-source agents lack robustness at this scale, while proprietary agents are powerful but opaque and hard to extend or control. The paper aims to close this gap with an open, transparent, and production-ready solution.
AI.method: The authors design the Confucius SDK around three perspectives—Agent Experience (how the agent reasons and uses memory), User Experience (how humans interact with the agent), and Developer Experience (how easily developers can extend and configure it). The SDK provides: (1) a unified orchestrator with hierarchical working memory for long-context reasoning; (2) a persistent note-taking system to support continual learning across sessions; (3) a modular extension framework for robust tool use. On top of this, they introduce a meta-agent that runs a build-test-improve loop to automatically synthesize, evaluate, and refine agent configurations for new tasks and environments. Using this SDK, they instantiate the Confucius Code Agent (CCA) specialized for software engineering.
AI.result: When applied to real-world software engineering tasks, the instantiated CCA shows strong practical performance. On the SWE-Bench-Pro benchmark, CCA attains a state-of-the-art Resolve@1 score of 54.3%, significantly surpassing previous coding agents on this metric.
AI.conclusion: The Confucius SDK and CCA together offer an open-source, transparent, and extensible foundation for building production-grade AI coding agents. By integrating hierarchical memory, persistent knowledge, modular tool orchestration, and automated configuration via a meta-agent, the framework narrows the gap between research prototypes and deployable industrial systems and facilitates large-scale agent development and deployment.

title: Interpretable Embeddings with Sparse Autoencoders: A Data Analysis Toolkit
summary: Analyzing large-scale text corpora is a core challenge in machine learning, crucial for tasks like identifying undesirable model behaviors or biases in training data. Current methods often rely on costly LLM-based techniques (e.g. annotating dataset differences) or dense embedding models (e.g. for clustering), which lack control over the properties of interest. We propose using sparse autoencoders (SAEs) to create SAE embeddings: representations whose dimensions map to interpretable concepts. Through four data analysis tasks, we show that SAE embeddings are more cost-effective and reliable than LLMs and more controllable than dense embeddings. Using the large hypothesis space of SAEs, we can uncover insights such as (1) semantic differences between datasets and (2) unexpected concept correlations in documents. For instance, by comparing model responses, we find that Grok-4 clarifies ambiguities more often than nine other frontier models. Relative to LLMs, SAE embeddings uncover bigger differences at 2-8x lower cost and identify biases more reliably. Additionally, SAE embeddings are controllable: by filtering concepts, we can (3) cluster documents along axes of interest and (4) outperform dense embeddings on property-based retrieval. Using SAE embeddings, we study model behavior with two case studies: investigating how OpenAI model behavior has changed over time and finding "trigger" phrases learned by Tulu-3 (Lambert et al., 2024) from its training data. These results position SAEs as a versatile tool for unstructured data analysis and highlight the neglected importance of interpreting models through their data.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces sparse autoencoder-based embeddings (SAE embeddings) as an interpretable and cost-effective way to analyze large text corpora, outperforming LLM annotations and dense embeddings on several data analysis tasks.
AI.motivation: Existing approaches to analyzing massive text datasets either use LLMs (accurate but expensive, hard to scale, and sometimes unreliable) or dense embeddings (cheap but opaque and hard to control). The authors want representations whose dimensions correspond to understandable concepts, enabling more targeted, trustworthy analysis of model behaviors, dataset biases, and semantic differences across corpora.
AI.method: The authors train sparse autoencoders to produce sparse, interpretable latent dimensions, then use these latent vectors as SAE embeddings of texts and model outputs. They evaluate these embeddings on four text analysis tasks: identifying semantic differences between datasets, discovering surprising concept correlations, clustering documents along user-specified conceptual axes via concept filtering, and property-based retrieval. They compare performance and cost against LLM-based annotation pipelines and standard dense embedding methods.
AI.result: SAE embeddings detect larger differences between datasets than LLM-based annotation pipelines while being 2–8x cheaper, and they identify biases more reliably. The concept-aligned dimensions allow users to filter or select specific concepts for downstream tasks, enabling controlled clustering and improving property-based retrieval beyond dense embeddings. Empirical case studies show they can reveal behavior shifts in OpenAI models over time and discover trigger phrases associated with behaviors learned by Tulu-3 from its training data. They also quantitatively demonstrate that Grok-4 clarifies ambiguities more often than nine other frontier models by comparing SAE-embedded responses.
AI.conclusion: Sparse autoencoder-based embeddings provide an interpretable, controllable, and cost-efficient representation for large-scale text analysis. They bridge a gap between LLM-based qualitative analysis and opaque dense embeddings, enabling deeper insight into datasets and model behaviors, including bias and behavior shifts over time. The work argues that interpreting models through structured analysis of their training and behavioral data is both feasible and under-explored, and positions SAEs as a strong tool for that purpose.

title: Sliding Window Attention Adaptation
summary: The self-attention mechanism in Transformer-based Large Language Models (LLMs) scales quadratically with input length, making long-context inference expensive. Sliding window attention (SWA) reduces this cost to linear complexity, but naively enabling complete SWA at inference-time for models pretrained with full attention (FA) causes severe long-context performance degradation due to training-inference mismatch. This makes us wonder: Can FA-pretrained LLMs be well adapted to SWA without pretraining? We investigate this by proposing Sliding Window Attention Adaptation (SWAA), a set of practical recipes that combine five methods for better adaptation: (1) applying SWA only during prefilling; (2) preserving "sink" tokens; (3) interleaving FA/SWA layers; (4) chain-of-thought (CoT); and (5) fine-tuning. Our experiments show that SWA adaptation is feasible while non-trivial: no single method suffices, yet specific synergistic combinations effectively recover the original long-context performance. We further analyze the performance-efficiency trade-offs of different SWAA configurations and provide recommended recipes for diverse scenarios. Our code is available at https://github.com/yuyijiong/sliding-window-attention-adaptation

AI.tldr: They study how to efficiently adapt full-attention pretrained LLMs to sliding-window attention at inference without losing long-context performance, propose a recipe bundle (SWAA) and evaluate trade-offs and best practices.
AI.motivation: Standard Transformer self-attention is quadratic in sequence length, making long-context inference very expensive. Sliding window attention offers linear complexity but, when naively applied at inference to models trained with full attention, leads to strong performance drops because the model was never trained with this attention pattern. The authors are motivated to understand whether and how existing full-attention LLMs can be retrofitted to use sliding window attention effectively, avoiding costly pretraining from scratch while retaining long-context capabilities.
AI.method: They propose Sliding Window Attention Adaptation (SWAA), a collection of five adaptation strategies and their combinations: (1) use sliding window attention only during the prefilling phase while retaining full attention for later tokens; (2) preserve global "sink" tokens that always attend broadly; (3) interleave layers with full attention and sliding window attention instead of switching all layers; (4) leverage chain-of-thought prompting during inference to help the model reason under the modified attention pattern; and (5) perform fine-tuning with sliding window attention enabled to reduce the train–test mismatch. They systematically test individual and combined configurations of these techniques on long-context benchmarks.
AI.result: They find that directly turning on sliding window attention for a full-attention-pretrained LLM significantly harms long-context performance. No single adaptation trick fixes this on its own, but specific combinations of their five methods can nearly or fully recover the original long-context performance while keeping the linear-time efficiency benefits of sliding window attention. They empirically characterize and compare different SWAA configurations in terms of accuracy and computational cost, identifying strong-performing settings under various constraints.
AI.conclusion: Full-attention-pretrained LLMs can be successfully adapted to use sliding window attention without re-pretraining from scratch, but this requires carefully designed adaptation recipes rather than a naive substitution of the attention pattern. The proposed SWAA strategies, especially in synergistic combinations, largely restore long-context performance while enabling more efficient inference, and their analysis offers practical guidance on how to choose configurations for different deployment scenarios.

title: Robust AI Security and Alignment: A Sisyphean Endeavor?
summary: This manuscript establishes information-theoretic limitations for robustness of AI security and alignment by extending Gödel's incompleteness theorem to AI. Knowing these limitations and preparing for the challenges they bring is critically important for the responsible adoption of the AI technology. Practical approaches to dealing with these challenges are provided as well. Broader implications for cognitive reasoning limitations of AI systems are also proven.

AI.tldr: The paper derives fundamental limits on how robust AI security and alignment can be, using an extension of Gödel’s incompleteness theorem, and discusses practical ways to cope with these limits.
AI.motivation: As AI systems become more powerful and widely deployed, ensuring their security and alignment with human values is crucial. However, there may be deep theoretical constraints—analogous to Gödel’s limits on formal systems—that prevent us from achieving perfect robustness or guarantees. The paper is motivated by the need to understand these intrinsic limitations so that AI safety work can be realistic and well‑grounded.
AI.method: The authors extend ideas from Gödel’s incompleteness theorem to formal models of AI systems and their reasoning or verification frameworks. They use information‑theoretic arguments to characterize what kinds of robustness, security, and alignment guarantees are provably unachievable. They then discuss how these abstract limits apply to real‑world AI architectures and propose practical strategies within those bounds.
AI.result: They prove that any sufficiently powerful AI system or its verification framework faces incompleteness‑like barriers: there exist true but unprovable statements about its own behavior and security properties. Consequently, one cannot obtain fully general, absolute robustness guarantees. They further derive information‑theoretic bounds quantifying these constraints and identify specific classes of reasoning and alignment guarantees that are impossible to certify in full generality.
AI.conclusion: Perfectly robust and provably secure/aligned AI is theoretically unattainable once systems reach a certain level of expressiveness and capability, due to Gödel‑style incompleteness and information‑theoretic limits. Nonetheless, by recognizing these constraints, we can design more realistic safety strategies—such as domain‑restricted verification, layered defenses, and monitoring—that work within these fundamental bounds. The work also implies inherent limits on AI cognitive reasoning about its own behavior and about security properties in general.

title: Cooperative Retrieval-Augmented Generation for Question Answering: Mutual Information Exchange and Ranking by Contrasting Layers
summary: Since large language models (LLMs) have a tendency to generate factually inaccurate output, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) has gained significant attention as a key means to mitigate this downside of harnessing only LLMs. However, existing RAG methods for simple and multi-hop question answering (QA) are still prone to incorrect retrievals and hallucinations. To address these limitations, we propose CoopRAG, a novel RAG framework for the question answering task in which a retriever and an LLM work cooperatively with each other by exchanging informative knowledge, and the earlier and later layers of the retriever model work cooperatively with each other to accurately rank the retrieved documents relevant to a given query. In this framework, we (i) unroll a question into sub-questions and a reasoning chain in which uncertain positions are masked, (ii) retrieve the documents relevant to the question augmented with the sub-questions and the reasoning chain, (iii) rerank the documents by contrasting layers of the retriever, and (iv) reconstruct the reasoning chain by filling the masked positions via the LLM. Our experiments demonstrate that CoopRAG consistently outperforms state-of-the-art QA methods on three multi-hop QA datasets as well as a simple QA dataset in terms of both the retrieval and QA performances. Our code is available.\footnote{https://github.com/meaningful96/CoopRAG}

AI.tldr: CoopRAG is a cooperative retrieval-augmented generation framework that improves multi-hop and simple QA by jointly refining retrieval and reasoning between a retriever and an LLM.
AI.motivation: LLMs alone often hallucinate, and existing RAG approaches for simple and multi-hop QA still suffer from incorrect retrievals and hallucinations. There is a need for a more tightly integrated collaboration between retrieval and generation components that can better guide document selection and reasoning.
AI.method: CoopRAG has the retriever and LLM cooperate, and also lets early and later retriever layers cooperate for reranking. The pipeline is: (i) decompose the original question into sub-questions and a reasoning chain, masking uncertain steps; (ii) use the enriched query (question + sub-questions + partial reasoning chain) to retrieve documents; (iii) rerank retrieved documents by contrasting representations from different layers of the retriever to better capture relevance; (iv) have the LLM reconstruct the full reasoning chain by filling in the masked positions using the retrieved evidence.
AI.result: On three multi-hop QA datasets and one simple QA dataset, CoopRAG achieves higher retrieval quality and better QA accuracy than previous state-of-the-art methods, indicating more faithful and effective reasoning with fewer hallucinations.
AI.conclusion: CoopRAG’s cooperative mechanisms between retriever and LLM, and among retriever layers themselves, lead to more accurate document ranking and reasoning chains, thereby improving both retrieval and answer quality in QA tasks compared to existing RAG approaches.

title: Modeling Narrative Archetypes in Conspiratorial Narratives: Insights from Singapore-Based Telegram Groups
summary:
Conspiratorial discourse is increasingly embedded within digital communication ecosystems, yet its structure and spread remain difficult to study. This work analyzes conspiratorial narratives in Singapore-based Telegram groups, showing that such content is woven into everyday discussions rather than confined to isolated echo chambers. We propose a two-stage computational framework. First, we fine-tune RoBERTa-large to classify messages as conspiratorial or not, achieving an F1-score of 0.866 on 2,000 expert-labeled messages. Second, we build a signed belief graph in which nodes represent messages and edge signs reflect alignment in belief labels, weighted by textual similarity. We introduce a Signed Belief Graph Neural Network (SiBeGNN) that uses a Sign Disentanglement Loss to learn embeddings that separate ideological alignment from stylistic features.
  Using hierarchical clustering on these embeddings, we identify seven narrative archetypes across 553,648 messages: legal topics, medical concerns, media discussions, finance, contradictions in authority, group moderation, and general chat. SiBeGNN yields stronger clustering quality (cDBI = 8.38) than baseline methods (13.60 to 67.27), supported by 88 percent inter-rater agreement in expert evaluations. Our analysis shows that conspiratorial messages appear not only in clusters focused on skepticism or distrust, but also within routine discussions of finance, law, and everyday matters. These findings challenge common assumptions about online radicalization by demonstrating that conspiratorial discourse operates within ordinary social interaction. The proposed framework advances computational methods for belief-driven discourse analysis and offers applications for stance detection, political communication studies, and content moderation policy.

AI.tldr: The paper develops a computational framework to detect and structurally analyze conspiratorial narratives in Singapore-based Telegram groups, showing that such discourse is embedded in everyday conversations rather than isolated echo chambers.
AI.motivation: Conspiratorial discourse online is growing but hard to study at scale: it is interwoven with regular conversation, not always explicit, and traditional community or topic detection methods assume clear separations (e.g., echo chambers). The authors want a way to automatically detect conspiratorial content and uncover how it is structurally embedded in broader digital communication ecosystems, especially in a non-Western, Singaporean context.
AI.method: They propose a two-stage framework. Stage 1: fine-tune RoBERTa-large to classify Telegram messages as conspiratorial or non-conspiratorial, reaching F1 = 0.866 on 2,000 expert-labeled samples. Stage 2: construct a signed belief graph where nodes are messages and edges encode agreement or disagreement in belief labels, weighted by textual similarity. On this graph they introduce SiBeGNN (Signed Belief Graph Neural Network), which uses a Sign Disentanglement Loss to learn embeddings that disentangle ideological alignment from stylistic similarity. They then apply hierarchical clustering to the learned embeddings to discover narrative archetypes and compare clustering quality against baselines using cDBI and expert evaluation.
AI.result: The RoBERTa classifier effectively distinguishes conspiratorial messages. SiBeGNN produces embeddings that, when clustered, reveal seven distinct narrative archetypes (legal, medical, media, finance, contradictions in authority, group moderation, and general chat) across more than half a million Telegram messages. SiBeGNN outperforms baseline approaches on clustering quality (cDBI = 8.38 vs. 13.60–67.27 for baselines), and experts show high agreement (88%) that clusters are coherent. Analysis of cluster content reveals that conspiratorial messages permeate diverse, routine topic clusters, not only those centered on skepticism or distrust.
AI.conclusion: Conspiratorial discourse in Singaporean Telegram groups is not segregated into isolated echo chambers but is interlaced with ordinary discussions about law, finance, health, media, and everyday matters. The proposed signed belief graph and SiBeGNN framework provides a more nuanced, belief-aware representation of discourse, enabling better clustering and analysis of ideological content. This challenges simplistic models of online radicalization and offers a toolset with broader applications in stance detection, political communication research, and the design of content moderation policies that acknowledge the embedded nature of conspiratorial narratives.

title: T-pro 2.0: An Efficient Russian Hybrid-Reasoning Model and Playground
summary: We introduce T-pro 2.0, an open-weight Russian LLM for hybrid reasoning and efficient inference.
