The model supports direct answering and reasoning-trace generation, using a Cyrillic-dense tokenizer and an adapted EAGLE speculative-decoding pipeline to reduce latency. To enable reproducible and extensible research, we release the model weights, the T-Wix 500k instruction corpus, the T-Math reasoning benchmark, and the EAGLE weights on Hugging Face. These resources allow users to study Russian-language reasoning and to extend or adapt both the model and the inference pipeline. A public web demo exposes reasoning and non-reasoning modes and illustrates the speedups achieved by our inference stack across domains. T-pro 2.0 thus serves as an accessible open system for building and evaluating efficient, practical Russian LLM applications.

AI.tldr: T-pro 2.0 is an open-weight Russian LLM optimized for hybrid reasoning (with or without chain-of-thought) and fast inference, released together with data, benchmarks, and an inference stack for reproducible Russian-language reasoning research.
AI.motivation: Existing large language models for Russian either lack strong reasoning capabilities, efficient inference, or openness in terms of weights and research assets. There is a need for a fully open, practically usable Russian LLM that supports explicit reasoning traces, offers low-latency inference, and comes with standardized datasets and benchmarks so the community can systematically study and improve Russian-language reasoning and applications.
AI.method: The authors build T-pro 2.0, a Russian-focused LLM that uses a Cyrillic-dense tokenizer to better encode Russian text and an adapted EAGLE speculative decoding pipeline to speed up generation. They train or fine-tune the model on a large instruction dataset (T-Wix 500k) to support both direct answers and reasoning-trace outputs. They also construct the T-Math benchmark to evaluate Russian reasoning, and release EAGLE inference weights plus a public demo exposing both reasoning and non-reasoning modes to quantify speed and capability trade-offs.
AI.result: T-pro 2.0 can operate either in concise answer mode or in reasoning-trace mode, maintaining strong Russian-language reasoning performance while benefiting from reduced inference latency thanks to the Cyrillic-optimized tokenizer and EAGLE speculative decoding. The public demo and benchmarks show measurable speedups from the inference stack and provide empirical evidence that the system is effective across multiple domains of Russian-language tasks, including math/reasoning as captured by T-Math.
AI.conclusion: T-pro 2.0 provides the community with an open, efficient Russian LLM solution for hybrid reasoning, accompanied by datasets, benchmarks, and inference components that make research and practical development reproducible and extensible. By releasing model weights, instruction corpus, reasoning benchmark, and speculative-decoding infrastructure, the work establishes a foundation for further advances in Russian-language reasoning systems and real-world LLM applications.

title: AgriRegion: Region-Aware Retrieval for High-Fidelity Agricultural Advice
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated significant potential in democratizing access to information. However, in the domain of agriculture, general-purpose models frequently suffer from contextual hallucination, which provides non-factual advice or answers are scientifically sound in one region but disastrous in another due to variations in soil, climate, and local regulations. We introduce AgriRegion, a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) framework designed specifically for high-fidelity, region-aware agricultural advisory. Unlike standard RAG approaches that rely solely on semantic similarity, AgriRegion incorporates a geospatial metadata injection layer and a region-prioritized re-ranking mechanism. By restricting the knowledge base to verified local agricultural extension services and enforcing geo-spatial constraints during retrieval, AgriRegion ensures that the advice regarding planting schedules, pest control, and fertilization is locally accurate. We create a novel benchmark dataset, AgriRegion-Eval, which comprises 160 domain-specific questions across 12 agricultural subfields. Experiments demonstrate that AgriRegion reduces hallucinations by 10-20% compared to state-of-the-art LLMs systems and significantly improves trust scores according to a comprehensive evaluation.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes AgriRegion, a region-aware RAG framework that reduces geographically inappropriate hallucinations in agricultural advice from LLMs by using geospatial metadata and localized, verified knowledge sources.
AI.motivation: General-purpose LLMs hallucinate or give scientifically correct but regionally inappropriate agricultural advice because they ignore local soil, climate, and regulatory differences. There is a need for a system that can provide trustworthy, location-specific agricultural recommendations and an evaluation benchmark to measure such capabilities.
AI.method: They design AgriRegion, a RAG framework that augments standard semantic retrieval with a geospatial metadata injection layer and a region-prioritized re-ranking mechanism. The knowledge base is restricted to verified local agricultural extension sources, and retrieval is constrained by geo-spatial filters. They also construct AgriRegion-Eval, a benchmark of 160 questions spanning 12 agricultural subfields to test region-aware advisory quality and hallucination rates.
AI.result: On the AgriRegion-Eval benchmark, AgriRegion reduces hallucinations by 10–20% compared with state-of-the-art LLM systems and yields significantly higher trust scores in a comprehensive evaluation framework.
AI.conclusion: Embedding geospatial awareness and curated, local expert sources into RAG pipelines substantially improves the fidelity and trustworthiness of LLM-based agricultural advisory. AgriRegion and the AgriRegion-Eval benchmark provide a foundation for robust, region-specific AI support tools in agriculture.

title: Semantic Reconstruction of Adversarial Plagiarism: A Context-Aware Framework for Detecting and Restoring "Tortured Phrases" in Scientific Literature
comment: 10 pages, 5 figures; unpublished manuscript; submitted to arXiv for dissemination
summary: The integrity and reliability of scientific literature is facing a serious threat by adversarial text generation techniques, specifically from the use of automated paraphrasing tools to mask plagiarism. These tools generate "tortured phrases", statistically improbable synonyms (e.g. "counterfeit consciousness" for "artificial intelligence"), that preserve the local grammar while obscuring the original source. Most existing detection methods depend heavily on static blocklists or general-domain language models, which suffer from high false-negative rates for novel obfuscations and cannot determine the source of the plagiarized content. In this paper, we propose Semantic Reconstruction of Adversarial Plagiarism (SRAP), a framework designed not only to detect these anomalies but to mathematically recover the original terminology. We use a two-stage architecture: (1) statistical anomaly detection with a domain-specific masked language model (SciBERT) using token-level pseudo-perplexity, and (2) source-based semantic reconstruction using dense vector retrieval (FAISS) and sentence-level alignment (SBERT). Experiments on a parallel corpus of adversarial scientific text show that while zero-shot baselines fail completely (0.00 percent restoration accuracy), our retrieval-augmented approach achieves 23.67 percent restoration accuracy, significantly outperforming baseline methods. We also show that static decision boundaries are necessary for robust detection in jargon-heavy scientific text, since dynamic thresholding fails under high variance. SRAP enables forensic analysis by linking obfuscated expressions back to their most probable source documents.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces SRAP, a system that detects and semantically reconstructs plagiarized scientific text that has been obfuscated by adversarial paraphrasing tools using “tortured phrases.”
AI.motivation: Automated paraphrasing tools are being used to hide plagiarism in scientific literature by replacing technical terms with unnatural but grammatical synonyms (“tortured phrases”), which threatens the integrity of the literature. Existing detectors rely on static keyword lists or generic language models, leading to high false negatives on new obfuscations and an inability to trace the original source. The authors want a method that both detects such adversarial paraphrasing and recovers the original wording and source documents.
AI.method: They propose SRAP, a two-stage framework. Stage 1 performs statistical anomaly detection using a domain-specific masked language model (SciBERT) to compute token-level pseudo-perplexity and flag suspicious, low-probability phrases in scientific text. Stage 2 performs semantic reconstruction: it uses dense vector retrieval (FAISS) to search a corpus for semantically similar original text and then applies sentence-level alignment via SBERT embeddings to infer the most likely original terminology and its source document. Detection relies on static decision boundaries rather than dynamic thresholds to remain robust in jargon-heavy domains.
AI.result: On a parallel corpus of adversarially paraphrased scientific text, zero-shot baselines cannot recover any original terminology (0.00% restoration accuracy). The proposed retrieval-augmented SRAP framework achieves 23.67% restoration accuracy, substantially outperforming these baselines. The authors also empirically show that static decision boundaries outperform dynamic thresholding for anomaly detection in high-variance, jargon-rich scientific language.
AI.conclusion: SRAP effectively detects adversarial paraphrasing in scientific texts and can partially reconstruct the original terminology and link it to probable source documents, enabling forensic analysis of obfuscated plagiarism. Static, globally set thresholds are important for robust anomaly detection in specialized scientific domains. The framework offers a practical step toward preserving the integrity of scientific literature against automated paraphrasing-based plagiarism.

title: The 2025 Foundation Model Transparency Index
summary: Foundation model developers are among the world's most important companies. As these companies become increasingly consequential, how do their transparency practices evolve? The 2025 Foundation Model Transparency Index is the third edition of an annual effort to characterize and quantify the transparency of foundation model developers. The 2025 FMTI introduces new indicators related to data acquisition, usage data, and monitoring and evaluates companies like Alibaba, DeepSeek, and xAI for the first time. The 2024 FMTI reported that transparency was improving, but the 2025 FMTI finds this progress has deteriorated: the average score out of 100 fell from 58 in 2024 to 40 in 2025. Companies are most opaque about their training data and training compute as well as the post-deployment usage and impact of their flagship models. In spite of this general trend, IBM stands out as a positive outlier, scoring 95, in contrast to the lowest scorers, xAI and Midjourney, at just 14. The five members of the Frontier Model Forum we score end up in the middle of the Index: we posit that these companies avoid reputational harms from low scores but lack incentives to be transparency leaders. As policymakers around the world increasingly mandate certain types of transparency, this work reveals the current state of transparency for foundation model developers, how it may change given newly enacted policy, and where more aggressive policy interventions are necessary to address critical information deficits.

AI.tldr: The paper presents the 2025 edition of the Foundation Model Transparency Index, showing a significant decline in transparency scores among major foundation model developers compared to 2024, with training data, compute, and post-deployment impacts being most opaque areas.
AI.motivation: As foundation model developers become increasingly powerful and influential globally, there is a critical need to understand and benchmark how transparent they are about key aspects of model development and deployment, especially given rising policy interest and potential regulation. The authors aim to track whether transparency is improving or deteriorating and to identify gaps that matter for governance and accountability.
AI.method: The authors update and extend their annual quantitative index—the Foundation Model Transparency Index—introducing new indicators related to data acquisition, usage data, and monitoring. They systematically evaluate a set of prominent companies (including new entrants like Alibaba, DeepSeek, and xAI) against these indicators to produce comparable transparency scores on a 0–100 scale.
AI.result: The 2025 Index shows a drop in the average transparency score from 58 (2024) to 40 (2025), indicating a reversal of previous improvements. Developers are particularly opaque regarding training data, training compute, and the monitoring and reporting of post-deployment usage and impacts. IBM scores exceptionally high at 95, while xAI and Midjourney have the lowest scores at 14. Members of the Frontier Model Forum cluster in the middle of the distribution, avoiding very low scores but not leading on transparency.
AI.conclusion: Transparency among foundation model developers is deteriorating overall, with critical information gaps around data, compute, and real-world impacts. While a few companies, notably IBM, demonstrate that high transparency is achievable, many major developers lag significantly. The authors argue that emerging and future policy interventions are necessary and should be more targeted and stringent to close these transparency gaps and ensure adequate disclosure in areas most relevant to societal risk and oversight.

title: Enhancing Next-Generation Language Models with Knowledge Graphs: Extending Claude, Mistral IA, and GPT-4 via KG-BERT
comment: This paper was accepted and scheduled for inclusion in the ICALT 2025 proceedings but was ultimately not published due to absence from the conference presentation. It appears in the official program booklet. Conference: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Learning Technologies (ICALT)
summary: Large language models (LLMs) like Claude, Mistral IA, and GPT-4 excel in NLP but lack structured knowledge, leading to factual inconsistencies. We address this by integrating Knowledge Graphs (KGs) via KG-BERT to enhance grounding and reasoning. Experiments show significant gains in knowledge-intensive tasks such as question answering and entity linking. This approach improves factual reliability and enables more context-aware next-generation LLMs.

AI.tldr: Integrates knowledge graphs into large language models using KG-BERT to improve factual accuracy and reasoning on knowledge-intensive tasks.
AI.motivation: LLMs are powerful for natural language processing but often hallucinate or produce factually inconsistent answers because they lack explicit structured knowledge. The paper aims to reduce these issues by grounding LLMs in external, well-structured knowledge sources.
AI.method: Use Knowledge Graphs combined with a KG-BERT architecture to align and inject structured entity and relation information into LLM processing, then evaluate on tasks that heavily depend on factual knowledge such as QA and entity linking.
AI.result: Experiments demonstrate notable performance improvements on knowledge-intensive benchmarks, particularly in question answering and entity linking compared to baseline LLMs without KG integration.
AI.conclusion: Integrating KGs via KG-BERT makes LLMs more factually reliable and context-aware, suggesting a promising direction for building next-generation grounded language models.

title: CP-Env: Evaluating Large Language Models on Clinical Pathways in a Controllable Hospital Environment
summary: Medical care follows complex clinical pathways that extend beyond isolated physician-patient encounters, emphasizing decision-making and transitions between different stages. Current benchmarks focusing on static exams or isolated dialogues inadequately evaluate large language models (LLMs) in dynamic clinical scenarios. We introduce CP-Env, a controllable agentic hospital environment designed to evaluate LLMs across end-to-end clinical pathways. CP-Env simulates a hospital ecosystem with patient and physician agents, constructing scenarios ranging from triage and specialist consultation to diagnostic testing and multidisciplinary team meetings for agent interaction. Following real hospital adaptive flow of healthcare, it enables branching, long-horizon task execution. We propose a three-tiered evaluation framework encompassing Clinical Efficacy, Process Competency, and Professional Ethics. Results reveal that most models struggle with pathway complexity, exhibiting hallucinations and losing critical diagnostic details. Interestingly, excessive reasoning steps can sometimes prove counterproductive, while top models tend to exhibit reduced tool dependency through internalized knowledge. CP-Env advances medical AI agents development through comprehensive end-to-end clinical evaluation. We provide the benchmark and evaluation tools for further research and development at https://github.com/SPIRAL-MED/CP-Env.

AI.tldr: The paper presents CP-Env, a controllable hospital simulation environment and benchmark to evaluate LLM-based medical agents on full, dynamic clinical pathways rather than static questions or short dialogues.
AI.motivation: Existing medical AI and LLM benchmarks mostly assess performance on static exams (e.g., multiple-choice questions) or short, isolated physician-patient dialogues. These settings do not reflect the real-world complexity of healthcare, where decisions unfold over time across multiple stages and specialties, with branching pathways and evolving information. The authors aim to fill this gap by creating a benchmark that can test LLMs on realistic, long-horizon clinical workflows and transitions between care stages, including triage, consultations, diagnostics, and team-based decision-making.
AI.method: The authors design CP-Env, a controllable, agent-based hospital simulation environment that models a realistic hospital ecosystem with patient and physician agents. Within CP-Env, they construct multi-stage clinical scenarios that cover the end-to-end pathway: triage, specialist consultations, diagnostic testing, and multidisciplinary team meetings. The environment supports branching and adaptive flows that mimic real hospital operations. They define a three-layer evaluation framework: (1) Clinical Efficacy (quality and correctness of medical decisions), (2) Process Competency (ability to follow and manage complex workflows and long-horizon tasks), and (3) Professional Ethics (adherence to ethical and professional standards). They then evaluate multiple LLMs within this environment, observing their behavior in these dynamic scenarios, including tool usage, reasoning patterns, and error modes like hallucinations and loss of key details.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation shows that most tested LLMs perform poorly when faced with the full complexity of dynamic clinical pathways. They often hallucinate information and fail to maintain or utilize critical diagnostic details over long interactions. The study also finds that more reasoning steps do not always improve performance and can sometimes harm it. Additionally, higher-performing models tend to rely less on external tools, suggesting more internalized medical knowledge and workflow understanding.
AI.conclusion: CP-Env provides a more realistic and comprehensive benchmark for assessing LLM-based medical agents in end-to-end clinical workflows. The results highlight significant current limitations of LLMs in handling complex, long-horizon medical decision-making and suggest that simply increasing reasoning verbosity is not sufficient. By releasing CP-Env and its evaluation framework, the authors aim to catalyze research on more robust, ethically aligned, and process-aware medical AI agents capable of operating safely within real-world clinical pathways.

title: Decoding Student Minds: Leveraging Conversational Agents for Psychological and Learning Analysis
comment: This manuscript is currently under peer review in Expert Systems with Applications
summary: This paper presents a psychologically-aware conversational agent designed to enhance both learning performance and emotional well-being in educational settings. The system combines Large Language Models (LLMs), a knowledge graph-enhanced BERT (KG-BERT), and a bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) with attention to classify students' cognitive and affective states in real time. Unlike prior chatbots limited to either tutoring or affective support, our approach leverages multimodal data-including textual semantics, prosodic speech features, and temporal behavioral trends-to infer engagement, stress, and conceptual understanding. A pilot study with university students demonstrated improved motivation, reduced stress, and moderate academic gains compared to baseline methods. These results underline the promise of integrating semantic reasoning, multimodal fusion, and temporal modeling to support adaptive, student-centered educational interventions.

AI.tldr: A conversational AI tutor uses multimodal signals and psychological modeling to improve students’ learning and emotional well-being.
AI.motivation: Existing educational chatbots typically focus narrowly on either academic help or emotional support, and often rely only on text. There is a need for systems that can simultaneously track and support both learning and affect, using richer multimodal information, to provide more adaptive and student-centered interventions.
AI.method: The authors design a psychologically-aware conversational agent that integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) with a KG-BERT model enhanced by a knowledge graph and a bidirectional LSTM with attention. The system fuses multimodal inputs—textual semantics, prosodic speech features, and temporal behavioral patterns—to classify students’ cognitive and affective states (e.g., engagement, stress, understanding) in real time. This classification then guides the agent’s adaptive responses during educational interactions.
AI.result: In a pilot study with university students, the system outperformed baseline methods, leading to higher motivation, reduced stress levels, and moderate improvements in academic performance.
AI.conclusion: Integrating semantic reasoning, multimodal fusion, and temporal modeling into a psychologically-aware conversational agent is a promising approach for enhancing both emotional well-being and learning outcomes in educational environments. The findings suggest that such systems can enable more adaptive and student-centered educational interventions.

title: An exploration for higher efficiency in multi objective optimisation with reinforcement learning
comment: 13th International Symposium on Intelligent Manufacturing and Service Systems, Duzce University, Duzce, Turkiye, 25-27 September 2025
summary: Efficiency in optimisation and search processes persists to be one of the challenges, which affects the performance and use of optimisation algorithms. Utilising a pool of operators instead of a single operator to handle move operations within a neighbourhood remains promising, but an optimum or near optimum sequence of operators necessitates further investigation. One of the promising ideas is to generalise experiences and seek how to utilise it. Although numerous works are done around this issue for single objective optimisation, multi-objective cases have not much been touched in this regard. A generalised approach based on multi-objective reinforcement learning approach seems to create remedy for this issue and offer good solutions. This paper overviews a generalisation approach proposed with certain stages completed and phases outstanding that is aimed to help demonstrate the efficiency of using multi-objective reinforcement learning.

AI.tldr: The paper discusses improving the efficiency of optimisation and search by using a pool of operators and a multi-objective reinforcement learning approach to learn good operator sequences.
AI.motivation: Optimisation algorithms struggle with efficiency, especially in how they perform move operations in the search neighbourhood. Using multiple operators instead of a single one is promising, but finding an optimal or near-optimal sequence of these operators is still an open problem, particularly for multi-objective optimisation where multiple goals must be balanced.
AI.method: The paper proposes and overviews a generalised approach that applies multi-objective reinforcement learning (MORL) to learn from experience which operators, and in what sequence, should be applied during optimisation. The approach is structured in stages/phases, some of which are already completed and some still outstanding, aimed at demonstrating the effectiveness of MORL for this purpose.
AI.result: The abstract suggests that preliminary stages show promise for improving efficiency via MORL-based operator management, though detailed empirical results are not given in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that a generalised multi-objective reinforcement learning framework is a promising remedy for efficiently managing operator sequences in multi-objective optimisation, and it outlines completed and future work stages that aim to demonstrate this efficiency.

title: Grammaticality Judgments in Humans and Language Models: Revisiting Generative Grammar with LLMs
summary:
What counts as evidence for syntactic structure? In traditional generative grammar, systematic contrasts in grammaticality such as subject-auxiliary inversion and the licensing of parasitic gaps are taken as evidence for an internal, hierarchical grammar. In this paper, we test whether large language models (LLMs), trained only on surface forms, reproduce these contrasts in ways that imply an underlying structural representation.
  We focus on two classic constructions: subject-auxiliary inversion (testing recognition of the subject boundary) and parasitic gap licensing (testing abstract dependency structure). We evaluate models including GPT-4 and LLaMA-3 using prompts eliciting acceptability ratings. Results show that LLMs reliably distinguish between grammatical and ungrammatical variants in both constructions, and as such support that they are sensitive to structure and not just linear order. Structural generalizations, distinct from cognitive knowledge, emerge from predictive training on surface forms, suggesting functional sensitivity to syntax without explicit encoding.

AI.tldr: The paper tests whether large language models show evidence of internal syntactic structure by seeing if they replicate classic grammaticality contrasts.
AI.motivation: To determine if the success of large language models reflects genuine sensitivity to hierarchical syntactic structure, rather than just surface-level patterns or linear order statistics.
AI.method: The authors probe several LLMs (e.g., GPT-4, LLaMA-3) using prompts that elicit graded acceptability judgments on sentences instantiating two classic syntactic phenomena: subject-auxiliary inversion (to test recognition of subject boundaries) and parasitic gap licensing (to test representation of abstract dependencies). They compare model judgments on grammatical vs. minimally altered ungrammatical sentences.
AI.result: Across models, the LLMs consistently assign higher acceptability to grammatical than to closely matched ungrammatical sentences in both subject-auxiliary inversion and parasitic gap configurations, indicating robust sensitivity to the relevant contrasts.
AI.conclusion: Because the models, trained only on surface text, nevertheless reproduce subtle grammaticality contrasts that hinge on hierarchical structure, the authors argue that predictive training induces functional sensitivity to syntax. However, this does not necessarily imply explicit symbolic representations or human-like cognitive knowledge of grammar.

title: ID-PaS : Identity-Aware Predict-and-Search for General Mixed-Integer Linear Programs
summary: Mixed-Integer Linear Programs (MIPs) are powerful and flexible tools for modeling a wide range of real-world combinatorial optimization problems. Predict-and-Search methods operate by using a predictive model to estimate promising variable assignments and then guiding a search procedure toward high-quality solutions. Recent research has demonstrated that incorporating machine learning (ML) into the Predict-and-Search framework significantly enhances its performance. Still, it is restricted to binary problems and overlooks the presence of fixed variables that commonly arise in practical settings. This work extends the Predict-and-Search (PaS) framework to parametric MIPs and introduces ID-PaS, an identity-aware learning framework that enables the ML model to handle heterogeneous variables more effectively. Experiments on several real-world large-scale problems demonstrate that ID-PaS consistently achieves superior performance compared to the state-of-the-art solver Gurobi and PaS.

AI.tldr: The paper extends the Predict-and-Search framework for solving mixed-integer linear programs to handle parametric MIPs with heterogeneous variables, proposing an identity-aware learning method (ID-PaS) that outperforms Gurobi and prior PaS methods on large real-world problems.
AI.motivation: Existing Predict-and-Search methods with machine learning have improved performance on MIPs but are mostly restricted to binary problems and ignore fixed variables, limiting applicability to practical large-scale, heterogeneous, parametric MIPs frequently seen in real applications.
AI.method: The authors generalize the Predict-and-Search framework to parametric MIPs and design ID-PaS, an identity-aware learning architecture where the predictive model incorporates variable identities and heterogeneity, producing tailored predictions to guide the search process toward good solutions in mixed and fixed-variable settings.
AI.result: Across multiple large-scale real-world benchmark problems, the proposed ID-PaS framework consistently outperforms both the commercial MIP solver Gurobi and the previous PaS approach in terms of solution quality and/or computational performance.
AI.conclusion: Identity-aware learning within an extended Predict-and-Search framework effectively handles heterogeneous and parametric MIPs, enabling ML-guided optimization to surpass a state-of-the-art solver and prior PaS variants on challenging real-world instances.

title: XDoGE: Multilingual Data Reweighting to Enhance Language Inclusivity in LLMs
comment: Accepted and presented at the LLMs4All workshop at the IEEE BigData 2025 Conference, Macau - December 8-11, 2025
summary: Current large language models (LLMs) are trained on massive amounts of text data, primarily from a few dominant languages. Studies suggest that this over-reliance on high-resource languages, such as English, hampers LLM performance in mid- and low-resource languages. To mitigate this problem, we propose to (i) optimize the language distribution by training a small proxy model within a domain-reweighing DoGE algorithm that we extend to XDoGE for a multilingual setup, and (ii) rescale the data and train a full-size model with the established language weights either from scratch or within a continual pre-training phase (CPT). We target six languages possessing a variety of geographic and intra- and inter-language-family relations, namely, English and Spanish (high-resource), Portuguese and Catalan (mid-resource), Galician and Basque (low-resource). We experiment with Salamandra-2b, which is a promising model for these languages. We investigate the effects of substantial data repetition on minor languages and under-sampling on dominant languages using the IberoBench framework for quantitative evaluation. Finally, we release a new promising IberianLLM-7B-Instruct model centering on Iberian languages and English that we pretrained from scratch and further improved using CPT with the XDoGE weights.

AI.tldr: The paper tackles the imbalance of languages in LLM pretraining data and proposes a method (XDoGE) to learn better language sampling weights, then trains Iberian-focused LLMs using these optimized distributions.
AI.motivation: LLMs are mostly trained on high-resource languages (especially English), which reduces performance on mid- and low-resource languages. The authors want to improve performance for underrepresented Iberian languages by optimizing how much data from each language is used during training.
AI.method: 1) Train a smaller proxy model with a domain-reweighting algorithm (DoGE), extended to a multilingual setting (XDoGE), to learn optimal language weights. 2) Use these learned weights to rescale the multilingual corpus and train a larger model either from scratch or via continual pretraining (CPT). They focus on six languages (English, Spanish, Portuguese, Catalan, Galician, Basque) and use Salamandra-2b and IberoBench for experiments.
AI.result: They show how over-representation of English and other dominant languages and heavy repetition for smaller languages affect performance. Using XDoGE-derived weights in pretraining and CPT improves results on IberoBench for the targeted languages. They also create and release IberianLLM-7B-Instruct, a 7B model optimized for Iberian languages and English, with improved performance over baselines.
AI.conclusion: Optimizing the language distribution in pretraining data via XDoGE leads to better performance on mid- and low-resource Iberian languages without severely sacrificing high-resource performance. Learned language weights can effectively guide both from-scratch training and continual pretraining, and the resulting IberianLLM-7B-Instruct is a strong open model for Iberian and English languages.

title: Reverse Thinking Enhances Missing Information Detection in Large Language Models
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in various reasoning tasks, yet they often struggle with problems involving missing information, exhibiting issues such as incomplete responses, factual errors, and hallucinations. While forward reasoning approaches like Chain-of-Thought (CoT) and Tree-of-Thought (ToT) have shown success in structured problem-solving, they frequently fail to systematically identify and recover omitted information. In this paper, we explore the potential of reverse thinking methodologies to enhance LLMs' performance on missing information detection tasks. Drawing inspiration from recent work on backward reasoning, we propose a novel framework that guides LLMs through reverse thinking to identify necessary conditions and pinpoint missing elements. Our approach transforms the challenging task of missing information identification into a more manageable backward reasoning problem, significantly improving model accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that our reverse thinking approach achieves substantial performance gains compared to traditional forward reasoning methods, providing a promising direction for enhancing LLMs' logical completeness and reasoning robustness.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a reverse-thinking reasoning framework for LLMs to better detect missing information, significantly improving accuracy over forward reasoning methods like CoT and ToT.
AI.motivation: LLMs, despite strong reasoning abilities, often fail on tasks where key information is missing, leading to incomplete answers, factual mistakes, and hallucinations. Existing forward reasoning techniques (CoT, ToT) improve structure but do not reliably detect or recover missing information. The paper is motivated by the need for systematic methods that help LLMs recognize when information is absent and reason about what is required for logically complete answers.
AI.method: The authors introduce a reverse thinking framework inspired by backward reasoning. Instead of reasoning only from given premises forward, the method guides the LLM to start from the goal or required conclusion and work backwards to identify necessary conditions and missing elements. They operationalize this as a prompting and reasoning procedure that reframes missing-information detection as a backward reasoning task, and compare it against CoT/ToT style forward reasoning on benchmark tasks involving incomplete or underspecified problems.
AI.result: Experiments show that the reverse thinking framework yields substantially higher accuracy on missing-information detection tasks than standard forward reasoning baselines such as Chain-of-Thought and Tree-of-Thought. The approach is more successful at explicitly identifying what information is missing and avoiding incomplete or hallucinated answers.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that reverse thinking / backward reasoning provides an effective way to help LLMs detect and reason about missing information. By transforming the task into a backward search for necessary conditions, the framework improves logical completeness and robustness over conventional forward reasoning methods, and represents a promising direction for future work on reliable LLM reasoning.

title: Causal Reasoning Favors Encoders: On The Limits of Decoder-Only Models
summary: In context learning (ICL) underpins recent advances in large language models (LLMs), although its role and performance in causal reasoning remains unclear. Causal reasoning demands multihop composition and strict conjunctive control, and reliance on spurious lexical relations of the input could provide misleading results. We hypothesize that, due to their ability to project the input into a latent space, encoder and encoder decoder architectures are better suited for said multihop conjunctive reasoning versus decoder only models. To do this, we compare fine-tuned versions of all the aforementioned architectures with zero and few shot ICL in both natural language and non natural language scenarios. We find that ICL alone is insufficient for reliable causal reasoning, often overfocusing on irrelevant input features. In particular, decoder only models are noticeably brittle to distributional shifts, while finetuned encoder and encoder decoder models can generalize more robustly across our tests, including the non natural language split. Both architectures are only matched or surpassed by decoder only architectures at large scales. We conclude by noting that for cost effective, short horizon robust causal reasoning, encoder or encoder decoder architectures with targeted finetuning are preferable.

AI.tldr: The paper evaluates how well different large language model architectures perform causal reasoning via in-context learning versus finetuning, finding that ICL alone is unreliable while finetuned encoder and encoder-decoder models offer more robust, cost-effective causal reasoning than decoder-only models at moderate scales.
AI.motivation: Although in-context learning drives much of the recent progress in large language models, its actual capabilities and limitations for causal reasoning—especially multihop composition and strict conjunctive control—are not well understood. The authors want to clarify whether relying on ICL, particularly in decoder-only models, is enough for robust causal reasoning or if other architectures and training strategies are better suited.
AI.method: The authors compare fine-tuned encoder, encoder-decoder, and decoder-only architectures against zero-shot and few-shot in-context learning using decoder-only models. They test the models on both natural language and non-natural-language tasks specifically designed to require multihop conjunctive causal reasoning, and they analyze robustness to distributional shifts and reliance on spurious lexical cues.
AI.result: They find that in-context learning alone is not sufficient for reliable causal reasoning: models tend to latch onto irrelevant input features and fail under distributional shifts. Decoder-only models in particular are brittle, especially when tested outside their training distribution. Finetuned encoder and encoder-decoder models, however, generalize more robustly across both natural language and synthetic (non-natural-language) tasks, though very large decoder-only models can match or exceed their performance.
AI.conclusion: For practical, cost-effective causal reasoning over short reasoning horizons, relying purely on in-context learning with decoder-only models is not ideal. Instead, encoder or encoder-decoder architectures with targeted finetuning offer more reliable and robust causal reasoning performance, unless one can afford very large decoder-only models that can close the performance gap.

title: Neuronal Attention Circuit (NAC) for Representation Learning
summary: Attention improves representation learning over RNNs, but its discrete nature limits continuous-time (CT) modeling. We introduce Neuronal Attention Circuit (NAC), a novel, biologically plausible CT-Attention mechanism that reformulates attention logits computation as the solution to a linear first-order ODE with nonlinear interlinked gates derived from repurposing \textit{C. elegans} Neuronal Circuit Policies (NCPs) wiring mechanism. NAC replaces dense projections with sparse sensory gates for key-query projections and a sparse backbone network with two heads for computing \textit{content-target} and \textit{learnable time-constant} gates, enabling efficient adaptive dynamics. NAC supports three attention logit computation modes: (i) explicit Euler integration, (ii) exact closed-form solution, and (iii) steady-state approximation. To improve memory intensity, we implemented a sparse Top-\emph{K} pairwise concatenation scheme that selectively curates key-query interactions. We provide rigorous theoretical guarantees, including state stability, bounded approximation errors, and universal approximation. Empirically, we implemented NAC in diverse domains, including irregular time-series classification, lane-keeping for autonomous vehicles, and industrial prognostics. We observed that NAC matches or outperforms competing baselines in accuracy and occupies an intermediate position in runtime and memory efficiency compared with several CT baselines.

AI.tldr: Proposes Neuronal Attention Circuit (NAC), a biologically inspired continuous-time attention mechanism based on ODEs and sparse circuitry, with theoretical guarantees and strong empirical performance across several domains.
AI.motivation: Standard attention mechanisms work well for representation learning but are inherently discrete in time and dense, making them poorly suited to continuous-time modeling and efficiency-constrained settings. The authors aim to design an attention mechanism that operates naturally in continuous time, is more biologically plausible, uses sparse connectivity, and still retains or improves performance and efficiency compared to existing continuous-time baselines.
AI.method: They introduce Neuronal Attention Circuit (NAC), which redefines the computation of attention logits as solving a linear first-order ODE with nonlinear gates. These gates are built using connectivity principles from C. elegans Neuronal Circuit Policies (NCPs): sparse sensory gates for key-query projections and a sparse backbone network with two heads that produce content-target and learnable time-constant gates. NAC supports three computation modes for attention logits: explicit Euler integration, an exact closed-form solution, and a steady-state approximation. Additionally, they design a sparse Top-K pairwise concatenation scheme to select key-query interactions, improving memory usage. They also provide theoretical analysis proving stability, bounded approximation error for numerical modes, and universal approximation properties.
AI.result: In experiments across irregular time-series classification, autonomous driving lane-keeping, and industrial prognostics, NAC achieves accuracy that matches or exceeds existing baselines. In terms of runtime and memory, NAC lies between several continuous-time baseline methods, indicating a favorable trade-off between performance and resource usage.
AI.conclusion: NAC is an effective continuous-time attention mechanism that is both biologically inspired and computationally efficient. By modeling attention logits via gated ODE dynamics, using sparse connectivity, and supporting multiple solution modes, it offers strong theoretical guarantees and empirical performance, suggesting it is a promising alternative to conventional discrete-time and dense attention mechanisms for continuous-time tasks.

title: RoleRMBench & RoleRM: Towards Reward Modeling for Profile-Based Role Play in Dialogue Systems
summary: Reward modeling has become a cornerstone of aligning large language models (LLMs) with human preferences. Yet, when extended to subjective and open-ended domains such as role play, existing reward models exhibit severe degradation, struggling to capture nuanced and persona-grounded human judgments. To address this gap, we introduce RoleRMBench, the first systematic benchmark for reward modeling in role-playing dialogue, covering seven fine-grained capabilities from narrative management to role consistency and engagement. Evaluation on RoleRMBench reveals large and consistent gaps between general-purpose reward models and human judgment, particularly in narrative and stylistic dimensions. We further propose RoleRM, a reward model trained with Continuous Implicit Preferences (CIP), which reformulates subjective evaluation as continuous consistent pairwise supervision under multiple structuring strategies. Comprehensive experiments show that RoleRM surpasses strong open- and closed-source reward models by over 24% on average, demonstrating substantial gains in narrative coherence and stylistic fidelity. Our findings highlight the importance of continuous preference representation and annotation consistency, establishing a foundation for subjective alignment in human-centered dialogue systems.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces RoleRMBench, a benchmark for evaluating reward models in role-playing dialogue, and RoleRM, a new reward model using continuous implicit preferences that better aligns with human judgments in subjective, narrative-rich interactions.
AI.motivation: Existing reward models work reasonably well for objective or task-oriented language tasks but perform poorly in subjective, open-ended domains like role play. They fail to capture nuanced, persona-grounded preferences and stylistic/narrative judgments. There is also a lack of systematic benchmarks focused on these role-playing capabilities, making it hard to measure or improve such models.
AI.method: 1) Build RoleRMBench, a benchmark focused on role-playing dialogue, decomposed into seven capabilities (e.g., narrative management, role consistency, engagement). 2) Evaluate general-purpose reward models on this benchmark, comparing their scores to human judgments. 3) Propose RoleRM, a reward model trained with Continuous Implicit Preferences (CIP), which frames subjective evaluation as continuous-valued pairwise preference learning under multiple structuring strategies to better represent nuanced human preferences. 4) Run comprehensive experiments comparing RoleRM to strong open- and closed-source reward models on RoleRMBench.
AI.result: On RoleRMBench, existing general-purpose reward models show large and consistent misalignment with human judgments, especially for narrative and stylistic aspects. RoleRM, trained with CIP, achieves more than 24% average improvement over strong baselines, particularly in narrative coherence and stylistic fidelity metrics.
AI.conclusion: Continuous preference representations and consistent annotation strategies are crucial for aligning LLMs with human preferences in subjective, role-playing dialogue. RoleRMBench provides the first systematic evaluation framework for this setting, and RoleRM demonstrates that CIP-based training can significantly improve reward model performance on nuanced narrative and stylistic dimensions, laying groundwork for better human-centered dialogue systems.

title: Investigating The Functional Roles of Attention Heads in Vision Language Models: Evidence for Reasoning Modules
summary: Despite excelling on multimodal benchmarks, vision-language models (VLMs) largely remain a black box. In this paper, we propose a novel interpretability framework to systematically analyze the internal mechanisms of VLMs, focusing on the functional roles of attention heads in multimodal reasoning. To this end, we introduce CogVision, a dataset that decomposes complex multimodal questions into step-by-step subquestions designed to simulate human reasoning through a chain-of-thought paradigm, with each subquestion associated with specific receptive or cognitive functions such as high-level visual reception and inference. Using a probing-based methodology, we identify attention heads that specialize in these functions and characterize them as functional heads. Our analysis across diverse VLM families reveals that these functional heads are universally sparse, vary in number and distribution across functions, and mediate interactions and hierarchical organization. Furthermore, intervention experiments demonstrate their critical role in multimodal reasoning: removing functional heads leads to performance degradation, while emphasizing them enhances accuracy. These findings provide new insights into the cognitive organization of VLMs and suggest promising directions for designing models with more human-aligned perceptual and reasoning abilities.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces an interpretability framework for vision-language models (VLMs) that identifies and studies specialized attention heads responsible for different steps in multimodal reasoning, using a new chain-of-thought style dataset called CogVision.
AI.motivation: Although VLMs perform well on multimodal benchmarks, their internal decision-making processes remain opaque. There is a need to understand how different components, especially attention heads, contribute to visual perception and reasoning, and to connect these mechanisms to human-like, stepwise cognitive processes.
AI.method: The authors create CogVision, a dataset that breaks complex multimodal questions into step-by-step subquestions aligned with specific perceptual and cognitive functions (e.g., high-level visual reception, inference). They use probing techniques on VLM attention layers to detect heads that are predictive of or specialized for particular subquestion functions, label these as functional heads, and analyze their sparsity, distribution, interactions, and hierarchy. They also conduct intervention experiments by ablating or amplifying these heads during inference.
AI.result: Across different VLM families, the identified functional heads are sparse and unevenly distributed across functions, yet they play central roles in mediating inter-modal interactions and forming hierarchical reasoning structures. Empirical interventions show that removing these functional heads significantly harms multimodal reasoning performance, while boosting them leads to better accuracy.
AI.conclusion: VLMs contain a sparse set of specialized functional attention heads that underpin their multimodal reasoning abilities. Understanding and manipulating these heads offers a path toward more interpretable and human-aligned vision-language systems, and suggests design strategies that explicitly leverage such cognitive-like organization.

title: AgriGPT-Omni: A Unified Speech-Vision-Text Framework for Multilingual Agricultural Intelligence
summary: Despite rapid advances in multimodal large language models, agricultural applications remain constrained by the lack of multilingual speech data, unified multimodal architectures, and comprehensive evaluation benchmarks. To address these challenges, we present AgriGPT-Omni, an agricultural omni-framework that integrates speech, vision, and text in a unified framework. First, we construct a scalable data synthesis and collection pipeline that converts agricultural texts and images into training data, resulting in the largest agricultural speech dataset to date, including 492K synthetic and 1.4K real speech samples across six languages. Second, based on this, we train the first agricultural omni-model via a three-stage paradigm: textual knowledge injection, progressive multimodal alignment, and GRPO-based reinforcement learning, enabling unified reasoning across languages and modalities. Third, we propose AgriBench-Omni-2K, the first tri-modal benchmark for agriculture, covering diverse speech-vision-text tasks and multilingual slices, with standardized protocols and reproducible tools. Experiments show that AgriGPT-Omni significantly outperforms general-purpose baselines on multilingual and multimodal reasoning as well as real-world speech understanding. All models, data, benchmarks, and code will be released to promote reproducible research, inclusive agricultural intelligence, and sustainable AI development for low-resource regions.

AI.tldr: Introduces AgriGPT-Omni, a unified speech-vision-text model and benchmark for agriculture, with a large multilingual agricultural speech dataset and tri-modal evaluation suite, outperforming general models on agri tasks.
AI.motivation: Multimodal LLMs have advanced, but agriculture lacks multilingual speech data, unified multimodal architectures specialized for the domain, and standardized benchmarks, especially for low-resource regions and languages.
AI.method: 1) Build a scalable pipeline to synthesize and collect agricultural speech from texts and images, producing a large multilingual dataset. 2) Train an agricultural omni-model with a three-stage process: textual knowledge injection, progressive multimodal alignment across speech, vision, and text, and GRPO-based reinforcement learning for better reasoning. 3) Design AgriBench-Omni-2K, a tri-modal agricultural benchmark with multilingual coverage, tasks, and standardized evaluation protocols and tools.
AI.result: AgriGPT-Omni, trained on the new dataset and pipeline, significantly outperforms general-purpose multimodal baselines on multilingual, multimodal reasoning and real-world agricultural speech understanding tasks according to the new benchmark.
AI.conclusion: A specialized unified multimodal model, plus a large multilingual speech dataset and tri-modal benchmark for agriculture, can substantially improve performance on agricultural reasoning and speech tasks, supporting reproducible research and more inclusive, sustainable AI for low-resource agricultural contexts.

title: Trustworthy Orchestration Artificial Intelligence by the Ten Criteria with Control-Plane Governance
summary: As Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems increasingly assume consequential decision-making roles, a widening gap has emerged between technical capabilities and institutional accountability. Ethical guidance alone is insufficient to counter this challenge; it demands architectures that embed governance into the execution fabric of the ecosystem. This paper presents the Ten Criteria for Trustworthy Orchestration AI, a comprehensive assurance framework that integrates human input, semantic coherence, audit and provenance integrity into a unified Control-Panel architecture. Unlike conventional agentic AI initiatives that primarily focus on AI-to-AI coordination, the proposed framework provides an umbrella of governance to the entire AI components, their consumers and human participants. By taking aspiration from international standards and Australia's National Framework for AI Assurance initiative, this work demonstrates that trustworthiness can be systematically incorporated (by engineering) into AI systems, ensuring the execution fabric remains verifiable, transparent, reproducible and under meaningful human control.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a governance-by-design framework—Ten Criteria for Trustworthy Orchestration AI—to embed accountability, auditability, and human control directly into AI system architectures.
AI.motivation: As AI systems take on more consequential decision-making, existing ethical guidelines and ad-hoc controls are inadequate to ensure institutional accountability and trustworthy behavior. There is a need to move from high-level principles to concrete architectures that can systematically enforce governance, transparency, and human oversight across complex AI ecosystems.
AI.method: The authors derive and formalize ten criteria for trustworthy orchestration of AI systems, inspired by international standards and Australia’s National Framework for AI Assurance. They design a unified Control-Panel architecture that operationalizes these criteria by integrating mechanisms for human input, semantic coherence across components, and robust audit and provenance tracking. The framework is positioned as an orchestration layer that governs all AI components, their users, and human participants, beyond just AI-to-AI coordination.
AI.result: The result is an assurance framework and architectural model—Trustworthy Orchestration AI—showing how governance properties can be engineered into the execution fabric of AI ecosystems. The framework demonstrates how to make AI operations verifiable, transparent, and reproducible while retaining meaningful human control, going beyond narrower agentic or coordination-focused approaches.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that trustworthiness in AI cannot rely on ethics guidance alone; it must be systematically engineered into system architectures. The proposed Ten Criteria and Control-Panel architecture provide a structured way to embed governance, auditability, and human oversight into AI ecosystems, offering a practical path toward verifiable, transparent, and accountable AI aligned with emerging assurance standards.

title: From Data Scarcity to Data Care: Reimagining Language Technologies for Serbian and other Low-Resource Languages
summary: Large language models are commonly trained on dominant languages like English, and their representation of low resource languages typically reflects cultural and linguistic biases present in the source language materials. Using the Serbian language as a case, this study examines the structural, historical, and sociotechnical factors shaping language technology development for low resource languages in the AI age. Drawing on semi structured interviews with ten scholars and practitioners, including linguists, digital humanists, and AI developers, it traces challenges rooted in historical destruction of Serbian textual heritage, intensified by contemporary issues that drive reductive, engineering first approaches prioritizing functionality over linguistic nuance. These include superficial transliteration, reliance on English-trained models, data bias, and dataset curation lacking cultural specificity. To address these challenges, the study proposes Data Care, a framework grounded in CARE principles (Collective Benefit, Authority to Control, Responsibility, and Ethics), that reframes bias mitigation from a post hoc technical fix to an integral component of corpus design, annotation, and governance, and positions Data Care as a replicable model for building inclusive, sustainable, and culturally grounded language technologies in contexts where traditional LLM development reproduces existing power imbalances and cultural blind spots.

AI.tldr: The paper critiques how AI and language technologies handle low-resource languages, using Serbian as a case, and proposes a CARE-based “Data Care” framework for more ethical, culturally grounded corpus and model development.
AI.motivation: To understand how structural, historical, and sociotechnical factors shape language technology for low-resource languages, and to critique the dominance of English-centric, engineering-first AI approaches that overlook linguistic and cultural nuance, especially for Serbian.
AI.method: Qualitative study based on semi-structured interviews with ten experts (linguists, digital humanists, AI developers), analyzing their perspectives on the challenges of developing language technologies for Serbian and similar low-resource languages.
AI.result: The study identifies key problems: historical loss of Serbian textual heritage; reliance on English-trained models; superficial transliteration practices; data and sampling biases; and corpus/dataset design that lacks cultural and linguistic specificity, leading to reductive, functionality-first solutions that reproduce power imbalances and blind spots.
AI.conclusion: The authors propose “Data Care,” grounded in CARE principles (Collective Benefit, Authority to Control, Responsibility, Ethics), as a framework that embeds bias mitigation into corpus design, annotation, and governance from the outset, offering a replicable, more inclusive and sustainable model for building language technologies for low-resource languages in the AI age.

title: InfoCom: Kilobyte-Scale Communication-Efficient Collaborative Perception with Information Bottleneck
comment: Accepted by the 40th AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence (AAAI-26)
summary: Precise environmental perception is critical for the reliability of autonomous driving systems. While collaborative perception mitigates the limitations of single-agent perception through information sharing, it encounters a fundamental communication-performance trade-off. Existing communication-efficient approaches typically assume MB-level data transmission per collaboration, which may fail due to practical network constraints. To address these issues, we propose InfoCom, an information-aware framework establishing the pioneering theoretical foundation for communication-efficient collaborative perception via extended Information Bottleneck principles. Departing from mainstream feature manipulation, InfoCom introduces a novel information purification paradigm that theoretically optimizes the extraction of minimal sufficient task-critical information under Information Bottleneck constraints. Its core innovations include: i) An Information-Aware Encoding condensing features into minimal messages while preserving perception-relevant information; ii) A Sparse Mask Generation identifying spatial cues with negligible communication cost; and iii) A Multi-Scale Decoding that progressively recovers perceptual information through mask-guided mechanisms rather than simple feature reconstruction. Comprehensive experiments across multiple datasets demonstrate that InfoCom achieves near-lossless perception while reducing communication overhead from megabyte to kilobyte-scale, representing 440-fold and 90-fold reductions per agent compared to Where2comm and ERMVP, respectively.

AI.tldr: InfoCom is an information-theoretic, communication-efficient collaborative perception framework for autonomous driving that reduces inter-vehicle data from MB to KB while maintaining near-lossless perception performance.
AI.motivation: Autonomous vehicles need precise environmental perception, but single-agent perception is limited by occlusions, sensor range, and viewpoint. Collaborative perception can alleviate this by sharing information between agents (e.g., vehicles), but practical networks cannot reliably support the megabyte-level data commonly assumed by existing methods for every collaboration step. There is a need for a principled way to minimize communication while preserving task-relevant information, rather than heuristically compressing or pruning features.
AI.method: The paper proposes InfoCom, an information-aware collaborative perception framework grounded in an extended Information Bottleneck (IB) formulation. Instead of conventional feature-level compression or selection, InfoCom uses an information purification paradigm to extract minimal sufficient statistics for the perception task under IB constraints. It consists of three key components: (i) Information-Aware Encoding, which learns to compress intermediate features into compact messages that retain maximal task-relevant information while discarding redundancy; (ii) Sparse Mask Generation, which produces lightweight spatial masks that indicate where collaboration is beneficial, incurring negligible communication overhead; and (iii) Multi-Scale Decoding, which reconstructs and aggregates shared information in a progressive, mask-guided way, focusing decoding capacity on informative regions instead of naive feature reconstruction across the whole scene.
AI.result: Experiments on multiple autonomous driving and collaborative perception datasets show that InfoCom preserves almost the same perception accuracy as high-bandwidth baselines (near-lossless performance), while dramatically reducing communication cost. The method brings communication from megabyte-scale to kilobyte-scale per agent, achieving about a 440× reduction compared with Where2comm and about a 90× reduction compared with ERMVP, without significant degradation in perception metrics.
AI.conclusion: InfoCom demonstrates that an information-theoretic, IB-based design can break the conventional communication-performance trade-off in collaborative perception for autonomous driving. By purifying and selectively sharing only minimal task-critical information and using mask-guided multi-scale decoding, it enables practical, low-bandwidth collaboration while maintaining high perception quality. This establishes a theoretical and algorithmic foundation for future communication-efficient multi-agent perception systems.

title: Textual Data Bias Detection and Mitigation - An Extensible Pipeline with Experimental Evaluation
summary: Textual data used to train large language models (LLMs) exhibits multifaceted bias manifestations encompassing harmful language and skewed demographic distributions. Regulations such as the European AI Act require identifying and mitigating biases against protected groups in data, with the ultimate goal of preventing unfair model outputs. However, practical guidance and operationalization are lacking. We propose a comprehensive data bias detection and mitigation pipeline comprising four components that address two data bias types, namely representation bias and (explicit) stereotypes for a configurable sensitive attribute. First, we leverage LLM-generated word lists created based on quality criteria to detect relevant group labels. Second, representation bias is quantified using the Demographic Representation Score. Third, we detect and mitigate stereotypes using sociolinguistically informed filtering. Finally, we compensate representation bias through Grammar- and Context-Aware Counterfactual Data Augmentation. We conduct a two-fold evaluation using the examples of gender, religion and age. First, the effectiveness of each individual component on data debiasing is evaluated through human validation and baseline comparison. The findings demonstrate that we successfully reduce representation bias and (explicit) stereotypes in a text dataset. Second, the effect of data debiasing on model bias reduction is evaluated by bias benchmarking of several models (0.6B-8B parameters), fine-tuned on the debiased text dataset. This evaluation reveals that LLMs fine-tuned on debiased data do not consistently show improved performance on bias benchmarks, exposing critical gaps in current evaluation methodologies and highlighting the need for targeted data manipulation to address manifested model bias.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes and evaluates an end-to-end pipeline to detect and mitigate representation bias and explicit stereotypes in text datasets used to train LLMs, showing it improves data fairness but does not reliably reduce model bias on existing benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Training data for LLMs contains harmful language, demographic imbalances, and stereotypes, and regulations like the EU AI Act require practitioners to identify and mitigate such biases, especially toward protected groups. However, there is little practical, operational guidance on how to systematically detect and mitigate different forms of data bias for specific sensitive attributes, and it is unclear how data debiasing translates into reductions in model bias.
AI.method: They design a four-stage pipeline for any configurable sensitive attribute: (1) automatically generate high-quality group label word lists with an LLM; (2) measure representation bias using a Demographic Representation Score; (3) detect and filter explicit stereotypes via sociolinguistically informed rules; and (4) counteract representation bias with Grammar- and Context-Aware Counterfactual Data Augmentation that synthetically rebalances demographic groups. They then apply this pipeline to gender, religion, and age in a text corpus and fine-tune several LLMs (0.6B–8B parameters) on the original vs. debiased data for comparative evaluation.
AI.result: On the dataset level, human validation and comparisons with baselines show that the pipeline substantially reduces both representation bias and explicit stereotypes in the text. However, when various LLMs fine-tuned on this debiased data are evaluated with existing bias benchmarks, the models do not consistently exhibit less bias, indicating a weak or unreliable link between this style of data debiasing and standard model-level bias scores.
AI.conclusion: The proposed pipeline is an effective, operational method for detecting and mitigating multiple types of bias in text datasets along configurable sensitive attributes, achieving measurable improvements in data fairness. Yet these data-level gains do not translate reliably into better bias scores for fine-tuned LLMs, revealing limitations of current bias benchmarks and suggesting that more targeted, model-aware data interventions and improved evaluation methods are necessary to meaningfully reduce manifested model bias.

title: EpiPlanAgent: Agentic Automated Epidemic Response Planning
summary: Epidemic response planning is essential yet traditionally reliant on labor-intensive manual methods. This study aimed to design and evaluate EpiPlanAgent, an agent-based system using large language models (LLMs) to automate the generation and validation of digital emergency response plans. The multi-agent framework integrated task decomposition, knowledge grounding, and simulation modules. Public health professionals tested the system using real-world outbreak scenarios in a controlled evaluation. Results demonstrated that EpiPlanAgent significantly improved the completeness and guideline alignment of plans while drastically reducing development time compared to manual workflows. Expert evaluation confirmed high consistency between AI-generated and human-authored content. User feedback indicated strong perceived utility. In conclusion, EpiPlanAgent provides an effective, scalable solution for intelligent epidemic response planning, demonstrating the potential of agentic AI to transform public health preparedness.

AI.tldr: Introduces EpiPlanAgent, an LLM-based multi‑agent system that automatically generates and validates digital epidemic response plans, improving completeness, guideline adherence, and speed versus manual planning.
AI.motivation: Epidemic response planning is critical but traditionally depends on slow, labor‑intensive manual work by experts, limiting scalability and timeliness. The authors want an automated, intelligent system that can rapidly produce high‑quality emergency response plans for outbreaks.
AI.method: They design EpiPlanAgent, a multi‑agent framework built on large language models. The system decomposes planning tasks, grounds them in relevant guidelines/knowledge, and uses simulation modules to iteratively generate and refine digital emergency response plans. Public health professionals then test EpiPlanAgent on real-world outbreak scenarios in a controlled evaluation.
AI.result: EpiPlanAgent-generated plans were more complete and better aligned with guidelines than traditional manually developed plans, while requiring far less time to produce. Expert reviewers found high consistency between AI-generated and human-authored plans. Users reported that the system was very useful in practice.
AI.conclusion: EpiPlanAgent is an effective, scalable tool for intelligent epidemic response planning. Its performance suggests that agentic AI powered by LLMs can substantially enhance public health preparedness and could transform how emergency response plans are developed and maintained.

title: Long-horizon Reasoning Agent for Olympiad-Level Mathematical Problem Solving
summary: Large language models (LLMs) have achieved significant progress in solving complex reasoning tasks by Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR). This advancement is also inseparable from the oversight automated by reliable verifiers. However, current outcome-based verifiers (OVs) are unable to inspect the unreliable intermediate steps in the long reasoning chains of thought (CoTs). Meanwhile, current process-based verifiers (PVs) have difficulties in reliably detecting errors in the complex long CoTs, limited by the scarcity of high-quality annotations due to the prohibitive costs of human annotations. Therefore, we propose the \textbf{O}utcome-based \textbf{P}rocess \textbf{V}erifier (OPV), which verifies the rationale process of summarized outcomes from long CoTs to achieve both accurate and efficient verification and enable large-scale annotation. To empower the proposed verifier, we adopt an iterative active learning framework with expert annotations to progressively improve the verification capability of OPV with fewer annotation costs. Specifically, in each iteration, the most uncertain cases of the current best OPV are annotated and then subsequently used to train a new OPV through Rejection Fine-Tuning (RFT) and RLVR for the next round. Extensive experiments demonstrate OPV's superior performance and broad applicability. It achieves new state-of-the-art results on our held-out \textsc{\thisbench}, outperforming much larger open-source models such as Qwen3-Max-Preview with an F1 score of 83.1 compared to 76.3. Furthermore, OPV effectively detects false positives within synthetic dataset, closely align with expert assessment. When collaborating with policy models, OPV consistently yields performance gains, e.g., raising the accuracy of DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-32B from 55.2\% to 73.3\% on AIME2025 as the compute budget scales.

AI.tldr: They introduce OPV, an outcome-based process verifier that checks summarized reasoning steps from long chains-of-thought, trained with iterative active learning plus RFT and RLVR, achieving state-of-the-art verification and boosting downstream reasoning model performance.
AI.motivation: Existing outcome-based verifiers only check final answers and miss errors in intermediate reasoning steps, while process-based verifiers struggle with long, complex chains-of-thought due to the high cost and scarcity of expert process annotations. There is a need for a verifier that can reliably inspect reasoning processes at scale without prohibitive annotation costs.
AI.method: They design OPV, an outcome-based process verifier that evaluates the rationale associated with summarized outcomes extracted from long CoTs, instead of the entire raw chain. To train it efficiently, they use an iterative active learning loop: in each round, the current OPV flags the most uncertain cases, experts annotate these, and the new data is used to train an improved OPV via Rejection Fine-Tuning and RLVR. This progressively strengthens verification capability with fewer expert labels.
AI.result: OPV achieves state-of-the-art verification performance on their held-out benchmark (ThisBench), reaching an F1 score of 83.1, surpassing larger open-source baselines like Qwen3-Max-Preview (76.3 F1). It reliably identifies false positives in synthetic datasets in a way that closely matches expert judgments. When used to oversee and collaborate with policy models, OPV significantly improves their performance, for example increasing DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-32B accuracy on AIME2025 from 55.2% to 73.3% under higher compute budgets.
AI.conclusion: Outcome-based process verification over summarized reasoning, combined with an iterative active learning framework using expert annotations, can deliver accurate, scalable verification of complex long CoTs. OPV not only advances the state of the art in verifier performance but also serves as an effective oversight module that boosts the reliability and accuracy of downstream reasoning models under RLVR-style training and deployment.

title: User-Feedback-Driven Continual Adaptation for Vision-and-Language Navigation
summary: Vision-and-Language Navigation (VLN) requires agents to navigate complex environments by following natural-language instructions. General Scene Adaptation for VLN (GSA-VLN) shifts the focus from zero-shot generalization to continual, environment-specific adaptation, narrowing the gap between static benchmarks and real-world deployment. However, current GSA-VLN frameworks exclude user feedback, relying solely on unsupervised adaptation from repeated environmental exposure. In practice, user feedback offers natural and valuable supervision that can significantly enhance adaptation quality. We introduce a user-feedback-driven adaptation framework that extends GSA-VLN by systematically integrating human interactions into continual learning. Our approach converts user feedback-navigation instructions and corrective signals-into high-quality, environment-aligned training data, enabling efficient and realistic adaptation. A memory-bank warm-start mechanism further reuses previously acquired environmental knowledge, mitigating cold-start degradation and ensuring stable redeployment. Experiments on the GSA-R2R benchmark show that our method consistently surpasses strong baselines such as GR-DUET, improving navigation success and path efficiency. The memory-bank warm start stabilizes early navigation and reduces performance drops after updates. Results under both continual and hybrid adaptation settings confirm the robustness and generality of our framework, demonstrating sustained improvement across diverse deployment conditions.

AI.tldr: A new VLN adaptation framework integrates user feedback and a memory-bank warm start to improve continual, environment-specific navigation performance and stability over existing GSA-VLN methods.
AI.motivation: Existing General Scene Adaptation for Vision-and-Language Navigation focuses on unsupervised, environment-specific continual adaptation without leveraging user feedback. This overlooks a natural, informative supervision source available in real deployments, and current methods suffer from cold-start issues and unstable performance during redeployment. The work aims to bridge this gap by incorporating human interactions to obtain higher-quality, environment-aligned training signals and by addressing cold-start degradation.
AI.method: The authors propose a user-feedback-driven adaptation framework for GSA-VLN.
