The framework systematically collects and converts user feedback—both navigation instructions and corrective signals during interaction—into high-quality training data that is aligned with the specific environment. This feedback is used for continual learning to adapt the navigation agent. Additionally, they introduce a memory-bank warm-start mechanism that stores and reuses previously acquired environmental knowledge when the agent is redeployed, helping to mitigate cold-start degradation and stabilize early navigation performance.
AI.result: On the GSA-R2R benchmark, the proposed method consistently outperforms strong baselines such as GR-DUET, yielding higher navigation success rates and more efficient paths. The memory-bank warm start improves early-stage navigation stability and reduces performance drops after model updates. The framework shows robust performance gains under both continual and hybrid adaptation settings.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating user feedback into GSA-VLN and leveraging a memory-bank warm-start mechanism leads to more effective and stable environment-specific adaptation for VLN agents. The framework provides robust, sustained improvements over existing methods across various deployment conditions, indicating its practicality for real-world VLN applications where user interactions are available.

title: TRIDENT: A Redundant Architecture for Caribbean-Accented Emergency Speech Triage
summary:
Emergency speech recognition systems exhibit systematic performance degradation on non-standard English varieties, creating a critical gap in services for Caribbean populations. We present TRIDENT (Transcription and Routing Intelligence for Dispatcher-Empowered National Triage), a three-layer dispatcher-support architecture designed to structure emergency call inputs for human application of established triage protocols (the ESI for routine operations and START for mass casualty events), even when automatic speech recognition fails.
  The system combines Caribbean-accent-tuned ASR, local entity extraction via large language models, and bio-acoustic distress detection to provide dispatchers with three complementary signals: transcription confidence, structured clinical entities, and vocal stress indicators. Our key insight is that low ASR confidence, rather than representing system failure, serves as a valuable queue prioritization signal -- particularly when combined with elevated vocal distress markers indicating a caller in crisis whose speech may have shifted toward basilectal registers. A complementary insight drives the entity extraction layer: trained responders and composed bystanders may report life-threatening emergencies without elevated vocal stress, requiring semantic analysis to capture clinical indicators that paralinguistic features miss.
  We describe the architectural design, theoretical grounding in psycholinguistic research on stress-induced code-switching, and deployment considerations for offline operation during disaster scenarios. This work establishes a framework for accent-resilient emergency AI that ensures Caribbean voices receive equitable access to established national triage protocols. Empirical validation on Caribbean emergency calls remains future work.

AI.tldr: TRIDENT is a dispatcher-support architecture for emergency calls that leverages Caribbean-accent-tuned ASR, LLM-based entity extraction, and vocal stress detection to support triage, treating low ASR confidence and vocal distress as useful signals rather than simple failures.
AI.motivation: Emergency ASR systems perform poorly on non-standard English varieties, particularly Caribbean English, which leads to inequitable emergency response and triage. There is a need for systems that can handle accent variability and code-switching, especially under stress, and still support established triage protocols even when ASR fails.
AI.method: The paper proposes TRIDENT, a three-layer architecture: (1) a Caribbean-accent-tuned ASR that outputs both transcriptions and confidence scores; (2) a large-language-model-based entity extraction module tailored to local clinical entities and triage indicators; and (3) a bio-acoustic module that detects vocal stress/distress markers. These layers jointly provide dispatchers with transcription confidence, structured clinical entities, and vocal stress indicators, all explicitly designed to feed into existing triage protocols (ESI, START) and to operate offline during disasters.
AI.result: No empirical evaluation is reported; instead, the paper presents an architectural design and theoretical justification grounded in psycholinguistics (stress-induced code-switching, basilectal shifts) and discusses deployment constraints for disaster scenarios. The main technical contribution is the integrated framework and the insight that low ASR confidence and stress markers can be treated as informative prioritization signals rather than system failures.
AI.conclusion: The work proposes a conceptual and architectural framework for accent-resilient, dispatcher-support emergency AI tailored to Caribbean English varieties. It argues that integrating ASR confidence, semantic entity extraction, and stress detection can help ensure equitable access to national triage protocols, even when callers code-switch or use heavily accented/basilectal speech. Future work will focus on empirical validation using real Caribbean emergency call data.

title: On the Collapse of Generative Paths: A Criterion and Correction for Diffusion Steering
summary: Inference-time steering enables pretrained diffusion/flow models to be adapted to new tasks without retraining. A widely used approach is the ratio-of-densities method, which defines a time-indexed target path by reweighting probability-density trajectories from multiple models with positive, or in some cases, negative exponents. This construction, however, harbors a critical and previously unformalized failure mode: Marginal Path Collapse, where intermediate densities become non-normalizable even though endpoints remain valid. Collapse arises systematically when composing heterogeneous models trained on different noise schedules or datasets, including a common setting in molecular design where de-novo, conformer, and pocket-conditioned models must be combined for tasks such as flexible-pose scaffold decoration. We provide a novel and complete solution for the problem. First, we derive a simple path existence criterion that predicts exactly when collapse occurs from noise schedules and exponents alone. Second, we introduce Adaptive path Correction with Exponents (ACE), which extends Feynman-Kac steering to time-varying exponents and guarantees a valid probability path. On a synthetic 2D benchmark and on flexible-pose scaffold decoration, ACE eliminates collapse and enables high-guidance compositional generation, improving distributional and docking metrics over constant-exponent baselines and even specialized task-specific scaffold decoration models. Our work turns ratio-of-densities steering with heterogeneous experts from an unstable heuristic into a reliable tool for controllable generation.

AI.tldr: The paper identifies and solves a key failure mode (Marginal Path Collapse) in inference-time steering of diffusion/flow models using ratio-of-densities, and proposes ACE to guarantee valid probability paths when composing heterogeneous models.
AI.motivation: Inference-time steering lets us adapt pretrained generative diffusion/flow models to new tasks without retraining, often by combining multiple models through ratio-of-densities. However, practitioners lack a theoretical understanding and safeguards for a critical failure mode where the composed probability path becomes invalid (non-normalizable) midway, especially when mixing heterogeneous models (different noise schedules or datasets) as in molecular design tasks like flexible-pose scaffold decoration.
AI.method: 1) The authors analyze the ratio-of-densities construction for time-indexed target paths and formally identify the condition under which marginal path densities become non-normalizable, naming this phenomenon Marginal Path Collapse. They then derive a path existence criterion that depends only on the models’ noise schedules and the chosen exponents, predicting collapse in advance. 2) They propose Adaptive path Correction with Exponents (ACE), an extension of Feynman-Kac steering that allows time-varying exponents. ACE dynamically adjusts exponents along the diffusion/flow trajectory to ensure that the overall probability path remains valid and normalizable while still enforcing guidance from all component models.
AI.result: On a synthetic 2D benchmark and a realistic molecular-design task (flexible-pose scaffold decoration), ACE prevents Marginal Path Collapse for heterogeneous model compositions and supports strong guidance. Empirically, ACE achieves better distributional alignment and docking performance compared to constant-exponent ratio-of-densities methods and even surpasses specialized models trained specifically for scaffold decoration tasks.
AI.conclusion: The work demonstrates that standard ratio-of-densities steering of diffusion/flow models can be fundamentally unstable when composing heterogeneous experts, due to Marginal Path Collapse. By providing a precise existence criterion and introducing ACE to correct paths via time-varying exponents, the paper converts this unstable heuristic into a principled and reliable method for controllable, compositional generation in settings such as molecular design.

title: OPV: Outcome-based Process Verifier for Efficient Long Chain-of-Thought Verification
summary: Large language models (LLMs) have achieved significant progress in solving complex reasoning tasks by Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR). This advancement is also inseparable from the oversight automated by reliable verifiers. However, current outcome-based verifiers (OVs) are unable to inspect the unreliable intermediate steps in the long reasoning chains of thought (CoTs). Meanwhile, current process-based verifiers (PVs) have difficulties in reliably detecting errors in the complex long CoTs, limited by the scarcity of high-quality annotations due to the prohibitive costs of human annotations. Therefore, we propose the Outcome-based Process Verifier (OPV), which verifies the rationale process of summarized outcomes from long CoTs to achieve both accurate and efficient verification and enable large-scale annotation. To empower the proposed verifier, we adopt an iterative active learning framework with expert annotations to progressively improve the verification capability of OPV with fewer annotation costs. Specifically, in each iteration, the most uncertain cases of the current best OPV are annotated and then subsequently used to train a new OPV through Rejection Fine-Tuning (RFT) and RLVR for the next round. Extensive experiments demonstrate OPV's superior performance and broad applicability. It achieves new state-of-the-art results on our held-out OPV-Bench, outperforming much larger open-source models such as Qwen3-Max-Preview with an F1 score of 83.1 compared to 76.3. Furthermore, OPV effectively detects false positives within synthetic dataset, closely align with expert assessment. When collaborating with policy models, OPV consistently yields performance gains, e.g., raising the accuracy of DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-32B from 55.2% to 73.3% on AIME2025 as the compute budget scales.

AI.tldr: They introduce Outcome-based Process Verifier (OPV), a verifier that checks summarized reasoning processes from long chains-of-thought, trained via iterative active learning plus RLVR/RFT, achieving better verification and boosting policy-model performance.
AI.motivation: Existing verifiers either check only final outcomes (OVs) and thus miss errors in intermediate reasoning, or check full processes (PVs) but require expensive, scarce human annotations to work reliably on long, complex chains-of-thought. There is a need for a verifier that can reliably inspect reasoning processes in a scalable, annotation-efficient way, to support RL with verifiable rewards and large-scale oversight.
AI.method: They propose OPV, an outcome-based process verifier that evaluates the rationale process of *summarized* outcomes derived from long chains-of-thought, balancing accuracy and efficiency. OPV is trained in an iterative active learning loop with expert labels: in each iteration, the current OPV selects its most uncertain cases; experts annotate them; these annotations are then used to train a new OPV via Rejection Fine-Tuning (RFT) and Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR). This progressively enhances OPV’s verification ability while minimizing annotation cost. OPV is then used as an automated verifier/annotator and as an oversight module collaborating with policy models.
AI.result: On their held-out OPV-Bench, OPV achieves state-of-the-art verification performance with an F1 score of 83.1, surpassing larger open-source models like Qwen3-Max-Preview (76.3 F1). On synthetic datasets, OPV reliably detects false positives in a way that closely matches expert judgments. When used alongside policy models, OPV yields substantial gains; for example, it improves DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-32B accuracy on AIME2025 from 55.2% to 73.3% as compute budget increases.
AI.conclusion: Outcome-based Process Verifier (OPV) offers a scalable and reliable way to verify reasoning processes by focusing on summarized outcomes, overcoming limitations of both pure outcome-based and full process-based verifiers. Through active learning with expert feedback plus RFT and RLVR, OPV achieves strong performance, aligns well with human assessments, and significantly boosts downstream model accuracy when used as an oversight component. This positions OPV as a practical foundation for large-scale automated oversight and annotation in complex reasoning tasks.

title: REMISVFU: Vertical Federated Unlearning via Representation Misdirection for Intermediate Output Feature
comment: The 40th Annual AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence
summary: Data-protection regulations such as the GDPR grant every participant in a federated system a right to be forgotten. Federated unlearning has therefore emerged as a research frontier, aiming to remove a specific party's contribution from the learned model while preserving the utility of the remaining parties. However, most unlearning techniques focus on Horizontal Federated Learning (HFL), where data are partitioned by samples. In contrast, Vertical Federated Learning (VFL) allows organizations that possess complementary feature spaces to train a joint model without sharing raw data. The resulting feature-partitioned architecture renders HFL-oriented unlearning methods ineffective. In this paper, we propose REMISVFU, a plug-and-play representation misdirection framework that enables fast, client-level unlearning in splitVFL systems. When a deletion request arrives, the forgetting party collapses its encoder output to a randomly sampled anchor on the unit sphere, severing the statistical link between its features and the global model. To maintain utility for the remaining parties, the server jointly optimizes a retention loss and a forgetting loss, aligning their gradients via orthogonal projection to eliminate destructive interference. Evaluations on public benchmarks show that REMISVFU suppresses back-door attack success to the natural class-prior level and sacrifices only about 2.5% points of clean accuracy, outperforming state-of-the-art baselines.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces REMISVFU, a fast, plug-and-play client-level unlearning framework tailored for split vertical federated learning (VFL), which removes a party’s influence while preserving the model’s utility.
AI.motivation: Existing machine learning regulations like GDPR require a right to be forgotten, but most federated unlearning methods target horizontal federated learning (HFL) and do not work well for vertical federated learning (VFL), where features rather than samples are partitioned across parties. There is a need for an efficient, practical unlearning mechanism that works with split VFL architectures and preserves model performance for the remaining parties.
AI.method: The authors propose REMISVFU, a representation misdirection framework for split VFL. When a client requests deletion, that client collapses its encoder outputs to a randomly sampled anchor on the unit sphere, breaking the statistical connection between its private features and the global model. Meanwhile, the server optimizes two objectives—a retention loss to preserve performance on non-forgotten data, and a forgetting loss to enforce unlearning. The gradients of these two losses are aligned via orthogonal projection to prevent them from interfering destructively, enabling efficient, plug-and-play client-level unlearning.
AI.result: Experiments on public benchmark datasets show that REMISVFU reduces backdoor attack success rates down to the natural class-prior level, indicating effective unlearning, while incurring only about a 2.5 percentage point drop in clean accuracy. It also outperforms existing state-of-the-art unlearning baselines in the split VFL setting.
AI.conclusion: REMISVFU provides an effective and efficient solution to client-level unlearning in split vertical federated learning systems. By misdirecting representations of the forgetting client and carefully balancing forgetting and retention through gradient alignment, the method achieves strong privacy guarantees (removal of a client’s influence and backdoor suppression) with minimal loss of model utility for the remaining participants.

title: Grow Up and Merge: Scaling Strategies for Efficient Language Adaptation
summary: Achieving high-performing language models which include medium- and lower-resource languages remains a challenge. Massively multilingual models still underperform compared to language-specific adaptations, especially at smaller model scales. In this work, we investigate scaling as an efficient strategy for adapting pretrained models to new target languages. Through comprehensive scaling ablations with approximately FLOP-matched models, we test whether upscaling an English base model enables more effective and resource-efficient adaptation than standard continued pretraining. We find that, once exposed to sufficient target-language data, larger upscaled models can match or surpass the performance of smaller models continually pretrained on much more data, demonstrating the benefits of scaling for data efficiency. Scaling also helps preserve the base model's capabilities in English, thus reducing catastrophic forgetting. Finally, we explore whether such scaled, language-specific models can be merged to construct modular and flexible multilingual systems. We find that while merging remains less effective than joint multilingual training, upscaled merges perform better than smaller ones. We observe large performance differences across merging methods, suggesting potential for improvement through merging approaches specialized for language-level integration.

AI.tldr: The paper studies how scaling up pretrained English language models helps adapt them efficiently to new, lower-resource languages, and how such adapted models can be merged into multilingual systems.
AI.motivation: Massively multilingual models often underperform language-specific models, especially at smaller scales, and adapting models to medium- and low-resource languages is challenging and data-hungry. The authors want to understand if making the base model larger (scaling) is a more efficient and effective way to adapt to new languages than standard continued pretraining, while also reducing catastrophic forgetting of English.
AI.method: They perform scaling ablations using approximately FLOP-matched models: starting from an English base model, they compare (a) standard continued pretraining on target-language data to (b) first upscaling the model (increasing size) and then adapting it to the target language with limited data. They then evaluate on language-specific tasks and English retention, and also experiment with merging separately adapted, upscaled language-specific models to form modular multilingual systems, comparing different merging methods with joint multilingual training.
AI.result: Upscaled models, when given enough target-language data, can reach or exceed the performance of smaller models that were continually pretrained on substantially more data, showing improved data efficiency. Larger scaled models also better preserve English capabilities, indicating reduced catastrophic forgetting. For constructing multilingual systems by merging, they find that while merging is still weaker than joint multilingual training overall, merges of upscaled models outperform merges of smaller models, and that different merging techniques yield substantially different performance levels.
AI.conclusion: Scaling up the base model is an effective and data-efficient strategy for adapting pretrained English LMs to new languages, allowing large models to match or surpass the performance of more heavily trained smaller ones while better preserving original capabilities. Although merging language-specific models is not yet as strong as joint multilingual training, larger upscaled models merge more successfully, and the significant variation across merging methods indicates room for specialized approaches to improve language-level model integration.

title: LLM-Empowered Representation Learning for Emerging Item Recommendation
summary: In this work, we tackle the challenge of recommending emerging items, whose interactions gradually accumulate over time. Existing methods often overlook this dynamic process, typically assuming that emerging items have few or even no historical interactions. Such an assumption oversimplifies the problem, as a good model must preserve the uniqueness of emerging items while leveraging their shared patterns with established ones. To address this challenge, we propose EmerFlow, a novel LLM-empowered representation learning framework that generates distinctive embeddings for emerging items. It first enriches the raw features of emerging items through LLM reasoning, then aligns these representations with the embedding space of the existing recommendation model. Finally, new interactions are incorporated through meta-learning to refine the embeddings. This enables EmerFlow to learn expressive embeddings for emerging items from only limited interactions. Extensive experiments across diverse domains, including movies and pharmaceuticals, show that EmerFlow consistently outperforms existing methods.

AI.tldr: Proposes EmerFlow, an LLM-based framework to generate strong embeddings for emerging items whose interactions slowly accumulate, improving recommendation performance with limited data.
AI.motivation: Recommender systems struggle with emerging items because they have few interactions. Existing approaches simplify the problem by assuming almost no history and fail to capture both the uniqueness of new items and their shared patterns with established items. There is a need for a method that can exploit limited but gradually growing interactions while maintaining item distinctiveness.
AI.method: EmerFlow is an LLM-empowered representation learning framework for emerging items. It (1) uses LLM reasoning to enrich raw features of emerging items, (2) aligns these LLM-enhanced item representations with the embedding space of an existing recommendation model, and (3) uses meta-learning to incorporate newly observed interactions, refining item embeddings as data accumulates. This pipeline yields distinctive and expressive embeddings for emerging items even under sparse interactions.
AI.result: Across multiple domains, including movies and pharmaceuticals, EmerFlow consistently achieves better recommendation performance than prior methods, demonstrating its effectiveness in handling emerging items with limited interaction data.
AI.conclusion: By combining LLM-based feature enrichment, representation alignment, and meta-learning over new interactions, EmerFlow can learn high-quality embeddings for emerging items from sparse and gradually growing data, outperforming existing approaches in various domains.

title: Script Gap: Evaluating LLM Triage on Indian Languages in Native vs Roman Scripts in a Real World Setting
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly deployed in high-stakes clinical applications in India. In many such settings, speakers of Indian languages frequently communicate using romanized text rather than native scripts, yet existing research rarely evaluates this orthographic variation using real-world data. We investigate how romanization impacts the reliability of LLMs in a critical domain: maternal and newborn healthcare triage. We benchmark leading LLMs on a real-world dataset of user-generated queries spanning five Indian languages and Nepali. Our results reveal consistent degradation in performance for romanized messages, with F1 scores trailing those of native scripts by 5-12 points. At our partner maternal health organization in India, this gap could cause nearly 2 million excess errors in triage. Crucially, this performance gap by scripts is not due to a failure in clinical reasoning. We demonstrate that LLMs often correctly infer the semantic intent of romanized queries. Nevertheless, their final classification outputs remain brittle in the presence of orthographic noise in romanized inputs. Our findings highlight a critical safety blind spot in LLM-based health systems: models that appear to understand romanized input may still fail to act on it reliably.

AI.tldr: The paper studies how using romanized Indian languages (instead of native scripts) affects LLM reliability for maternal and newborn health triage, finding substantial performance drops and revealing a safety blind spot.
AI.motivation: LLMs are being used in high-stakes clinical settings in India, where many users type Indian languages in romanized form. However, current evaluations largely ignore this orthographic variation and rely on native scripts or synthetic data. This gap raises concerns that LLMs may be less reliable for real-world users who commonly use romanized text, particularly in critical domains such as maternal and newborn healthcare triage.
AI.method: The authors construct a real-world benchmark of user-generated triage queries related to maternal and newborn health, covering five Indian languages and Nepali, each in both native script and romanized form. They evaluate leading LLMs on this dataset, measuring performance differences (e.g., F1 scores) between native-script and romanized inputs. They further analyze whether performance gaps stem from failures in clinical reasoning or from sensitivity to orthographic noise in romanized text, examining whether models can infer semantic intent but still misclassify.
AI.result: Across all evaluated LLMs, messages written in romanized form consistently yield lower performance than those in native scripts, with F1 scores for romanized inputs lagging by 5–12 points. Extrapolating to their partner maternal health organization’s deployment scale, this performance gap implies up to ~2 million additional triage errors. Analysis shows that the gap is not primarily due to misunderstanding medical content: models often correctly grasp the semantic intent of romanized queries but still produce incorrect or unstable final classifications when orthographic variations and noise are present.
AI.conclusion: Romanization of Indian languages introduces a significant and dangerous reliability gap for LLM-based maternal and newborn health triage, even when models appear to understand the user’s intent. The brittleness of final classification decisions in the presence of orthographic noise exposes a critical safety blind spot: systems that seem competent on standard benchmarks and native-script inputs may fail users who rely on romanized text. The authors imply that robust handling and explicit evaluation of romanized inputs is essential before safely deploying LLMs in such high-stakes clinical contexts.

title: AgentProg: Empowering Long-Horizon GUI Agents with Program-Guided Context Management
summary: The rapid development of mobile GUI agents has stimulated growing research interest in long-horizon task automation. However, building agents for these tasks faces a critical bottleneck: the reliance on ever-expanding interaction history incurs substantial context overhead. Existing context management and compression techniques often fail to preserve vital semantic information, leading to degraded task performance. We propose AgentProg, a program-guided approach for agent context management that reframes the interaction history as a program with variables and control flow. By organizing information according to the structure of program, this structure provides a principled mechanism to determine which information should be retained and which can be discarded. We further integrate a global belief state mechanism inspired by Belief MDP framework to handle partial observability and adapt to unexpected environmental changes. Experiments on AndroidWorld and our extended long-horizon task suite demonstrate that AgentProg has achieved the state-of-the-art success rates on these benchmarks. More importantly, it maintains robust performance on long-horizon tasks while baseline methods experience catastrophic degradation. Our system is open-sourced at https://github.com/MobileLLM/AgentProg.

AI.tldr: AgentProg introduces a program-structured context management system for mobile GUI agents that preserves essential interaction semantics and scales to long-horizon tasks, achieving state-of-the-art performance and robustness.
AI.motivation: Long-horizon mobile GUI automation agents accumulate large interaction histories, causing context length explosion and overhead for LLM-based reasoning. Existing context compression or selection often drops semantically crucial information, especially under partial observability and environment changes, which severely hurts task success. A more principled, structured way to represent and manage history is needed.
AI.method: AgentProg represents an agent’s interaction history as a program with explicit variables and control flow, using this structure to decide what information to retain or discard. It augments this with a global belief state mechanism, inspired by Belief MDPs, to track hidden or uncertain environment aspects and to adapt when the environment unexpectedly changes. The system is implemented for mobile GUI agents and evaluated on AndroidWorld and a newly extended long-horizon benchmark suite.
AI.result: On AndroidWorld and the extended long-horizon task suite, AgentProg achieves state-of-the-art success rates, particularly outperforming baselines on very long tasks where other methods suffer catastrophic performance degradation. Its structured program-based context and belief-state mechanisms maintain high success while keeping context overhead manageable.
AI.conclusion: Structuring interaction history as a program and maintaining a global belief state yields a principled, efficient context management approach for mobile GUI agents. This design preserves essential semantics, handles partial observability and environmental shifts, and scales robustly to long-horizon tasks, setting a new performance baseline and demonstrating a practical path toward more scalable GUI agents.

title: The FACTS Leaderboard: A Comprehensive Benchmark for Large Language Model Factuality
summary: We introduce The FACTS Leaderboard, an online leaderboard suite and associated set of benchmarks that comprehensively evaluates the ability of language models to generate factually accurate text across diverse scenarios. The suite provides a holistic measure of factuality by aggregating the performance of models on four distinct sub-leaderboards: (1) FACTS Multimodal, which measures the factuality of responses to image-based questions; (2) FACTS Parametric, which assesses models' world knowledge by answering closed-book factoid questions from internal parameters; (3) FACTS Search, which evaluates factuality in information-seeking scenarios, where the model must use a search API; and (4) FACTS Grounding (v2), which evaluates whether long-form responses are grounded in provided documents, featuring significantly improved judge models. Each sub-leaderboard employs automated judge models to score model responses, and the final suite score is an average of the four components, designed to provide a robust and balanced assessment of a model's overall factuality. The FACTS Leaderboard Suite will be actively maintained, containing both public and private splits to allow for external participation while guarding its integrity. It can be found at https://www.kaggle.com/benchmarks/google/facts .

AI.tldr: FACTS Leaderboard is a benchmark suite that evaluates factuality of language models across multimodal, parametric, search-based, and grounding tasks using automated judges and a combined score.
AI.motivation: Current LLM benchmarks typically evaluate narrow aspects of factuality or single task settings. There is a need for a comprehensive, unified, and actively maintained benchmark that measures how factually accurate models are in diverse, realistic usage scenarios, including multimodal inputs, closed-book knowledge, search-augmented tasks, and document-grounded generation.
AI.method: The authors build an online leaderboard suite composed of four sub-leaderboards: (1) Multimodal factuality on image-based questions; (2) Parametric factuality via closed-book factoid QA; (3) Search-based factuality where models must use a search API in information-seeking tasks; and (4) Grounding (v2), which measures how well long-form answers are supported by provided documents using improved judge models. Each sub-leaderboard uses automated LLM judge models to score outputs, and the overall FACTS score is the mean across the four components. The benchmark includes both public and private splits and is hosted as a Kaggle benchmark to enable community participation while controlling for overfitting.
AI.result: They provide a functioning, publicly accessible leaderboard suite where different language models can be evaluated and ranked on standardized factuality metrics across the four dimensions. The abstract emphasizes that the Grounding v2 sub-benchmark uses significantly improved judge models and that the suite already integrates these automated judges to score systems consistently.
AI.conclusion: The FACTS Leaderboard Suite offers a holistic, robust, and balanced way to assess the factual accuracy of language models across key real-world scenarios. By combining multimodal, parametric, search-augmented, and document-grounded factuality into a single actively maintained leaderboard with public and private splits, it aims to become a standard reference for evaluating and comparing LLM factuality.

title: Boosting RL-Based Visual Reasoning with Selective Adversarial Entropy Intervention
summary: Recently, reinforcement learning (RL) has become a common choice in enhancing the reasoning capabilities of vision-language models (VLMs). Considering existing RL- based finetuning methods, entropy intervention turns out to be an effective way to benefit exploratory ability, thereby improving policy performance. Notably, most existing stud- ies intervene in entropy by simply controlling the update of specific tokens during policy optimization of RL. They ig- nore the entropy intervention during the RL sampling that can boost the performance of GRPO by improving the di- versity of responses. In this paper, we propose Selective- adversarial Entropy Intervention, namely SaEI, which en- hances policy entropy by distorting the visual input with the token-selective adversarial objective coming from the en- tropy of sampled responses. Specifically, we first propose entropy-guided adversarial sampling (EgAS) that formu- lates the entropy of sampled responses as an adversarial ob- jective. Then, the corresponding adversarial gradient can be used to attack the visual input for producing adversarial samples, allowing the policy model to explore a larger an- swer space during RL sampling. Then, we propose token- selective entropy computation (TsEC) to maximize the ef- fectiveness of adversarial attack in EgAS without distorting factual knowledge within VLMs. Extensive experiments on both in-domain and out-of-domain datasets show that our proposed method can greatly improve policy exploration via entropy intervention, to boost reasoning capabilities. Code will be released once the paper is accepted.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes SaEI, a method that improves vision-language model reasoning by enhancing policy entropy through adversarially perturbed visual inputs during RL sampling, rather than only adjusting token entropy during optimization.
AI.motivation: Existing RL-based fine-tuning for VLMs often improves exploration by intervening in entropy, but mainly during policy optimization and via token-wise control. They largely ignore entropy intervention during the sampling phase, missing an opportunity to enhance response diversity and thus limit the performance of methods like GRPO. The authors aim to better exploit entropy to encourage broader exploration and stronger reasoning in VLMs.
AI.method: They introduce Selective-adversarial Entropy Intervention (SaEI). First, Entropy-guided Adversarial Sampling (EgAS) treats the entropy of sampled responses as an adversarial objective: gradients of this objective are backpropagated to the visual input to create adversarial visual perturbations, which are then used in RL sampling to broaden the model’s answer space. Second, Token-selective Entropy Computation (TsEC) refines which tokens’ entropy is used to drive the adversarial objective, so that perturbations maximize exploratory benefits while avoiding corruption of core factual knowledge in the VLM.
AI.result: On both in-domain and out-of-domain benchmarks, SaEI significantly improves exploration and reasoning performance of VLMs, outperforming baselines that only apply entropy intervention at the token-update stage in RL optimization. The improvements are attributed to more diverse response sampling and better use of adversarial visual perturbations during RL.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating entropy-guided adversarial perturbations into the RL sampling process, and doing so selectively at the token level, is an effective way to increase policy entropy and exploration for VLMs. This leads to better reasoning capabilities than conventional entropy intervention strategies that act only during optimization. The proposed SaEI framework provides a practical and more powerful way to harness entropy intervention in RL-based fine-tuning of VLMs.

title: LabelFusion: Learning to Fuse LLMs and Transformer Classifiers for Robust Text Classification
summary: LabelFusion is a fusion ensemble for text classification that learns to combine a traditional transformer-based classifier (e.g., RoBERTa) with one or more Large Language Models (LLMs such as OpenAI GPT, Google Gemini, or DeepSeek) to deliver accurate and cost-aware predictions across multi-class and multi-label tasks. The package provides a simple high-level interface (AutoFusionClassifier) that trains the full pipeline end-to-end with minimal configuration, and a flexible API for advanced users. Under the hood, LabelFusion integrates vector signals from both sources by concatenating the ML backbone's embeddings with the LLM-derived per-class scores -- obtained through structured prompt-engineering strategies -- and feeds this joint representation into a compact multi-layer perceptron (FusionMLP) that produces the final prediction. This learned fusion approach captures complementary strengths of LLM reasoning and traditional transformer-based classifiers, yielding robust performance across domains -- achieving 92.4% accuracy on AG News and 92.3% on 10-class Reuters 21578 topic classification -- while enabling practical trade-offs between accuracy, latency, and cost.

AI.tldr: LabelFusion is an ensemble framework that fuses a standard transformer classifier with LLM-based signals via a small MLP to improve text classification accuracy and cost-efficiency.
AI.motivation: LLMs offer strong reasoning ability but are costly and slow for large-scale text classification, while traditional transformer classifiers are efficient but may underperform on some tasks. There is a need for a method that combines their complementary strengths, providing high accuracy with controllable latency and monetary cost across diverse classification settings.
AI.method: LabelFusion trains a transformer backbone (e.g., RoBERTa) and queries one or more LLMs using structured prompts to obtain per-class scores. It concatenates the backbone’s vector embeddings with these LLM-derived class scores and passes the joint representation into a compact multi-layer perceptron (FusionMLP). The system is exposed via a high-level AutoFusionClassifier for end-to-end training and a lower-level API for expert control. The learned fusion determines how much to trust each component per example and per class.
AI.result: On benchmark text classification tasks like AG News and 10-class Reuters 21578, LabelFusion achieves accuracies of 92.4% and 92.3%, respectively, showing robust performance across domains. The design allows practitioners to choose operating points that balance accuracy against inference latency and API cost from querying external LLMs.
AI.conclusion: A learned fusion of transformer-based classifiers and LLM-derived signals can outperform or match either component alone while remaining practical for real-world deployment. LabelFusion operationalizes this idea with an accessible interface, flexible configuration, and demonstrated gains on multi-class topic classification benchmarks, making LLM-augmented classification more cost-aware and scalable.

title: Representation of the structure of graphs by sequences of instructions
summary: The representation of graphs is commonly based on the adjacency matrix concept. This formulation is the foundation of most algebraic and computational approaches to graph processing. The advent of deep learning language models offers a wide range of powerful computational models that are specialized in the processing of text. However, current procedures to represent graphs are not amenable to processing by these models. In this work, a new method to represent graphs is proposed. It represents the adjacency matrix of a graph by a string of simple instructions. The instructions build the adjacency matrix step by step. The transformation is reversible, i.e. given a graph the string can be produced and vice versa. The proposed representation is compact and it maintains the local structural patterns of the graph. Therefore, it is envisaged that it could be useful to boost the processing of graphs by deep learning models. A tentative computational experiment is reported, with favorable results.

AI.tldr: They propose a reversible way to serialize a graph’s adjacency matrix into a compact sequence of simple textual instructions, making graphs more suitable for deep-learning language models.
AI.motivation: Standard graph representations (like adjacency matrices) are not in a form that modern deep learning language models, which expect text, can easily consume. The authors want a representation that bridges graph data and text-based models while preserving local graph structure and being compact and reversible.
AI.method: They define a procedure that encodes the adjacency matrix as a string of simple instructions that iteratively construct the matrix. Each instruction modifies or extends the matrix so that, when the sequence is executed in order, the full adjacency matrix is recovered. They ensure that this mapping is bijective so the original graph can be reconstructed from the string. They then run a small computational experiment to test the approach.
AI.result: They show that the new representation is compact, preserves local structural patterns of the original graph, and that preliminary computational experiments (likely involving applying some deep learning models to the encoded graphs) yield favorable performance, suggesting practical viability.
AI.conclusion: A new, compact, and reversible instruction-string representation of graphs is feasible and appears to preserve important structural information while being compatible with deep-learning language models. Early experiments are promising, indicating this encoding could enhance graph processing with text-based deep models, though more extensive evaluation is still needed.

title: Targeted Data Protection for Diffusion Model by Matching Training Trajectory
summary: Recent advancements in diffusion models have made fine-tuning text-to-image models for personalization increasingly accessible, but have also raised significant concerns regarding unauthorized data usage and privacy infringement. Current protection methods are limited to passively degrading image quality, failing to achieve stable control. While Targeted Data Protection (TDP) offers a promising paradigm for active redirection toward user-specified target concepts, existing TDP attempts suffer from poor controllability due to snapshot-matching approaches that fail to account for complete learning dynamics. We introduce TAFAP (Trajectory Alignment via Fine-tuning with Adversarial Perturbations), the first method to successfully achieve effective TDP by controlling the entire training trajectory. Unlike snapshot-based methods whose protective influence is easily diluted as training progresses, TAFAP employs trajectory-matching inspired by dataset distillation to enforce persistent, verifiable transformations throughout fine-tuning. We validate our method through extensive experiments, demonstrating the first successful targeted transformation in diffusion models with simultaneous control over both identity and visual patterns. TAFAP significantly outperforms existing TDP attempts, achieving robust redirection toward target concepts while maintaining high image quality. This work enables verifiable safeguards and provides a new framework for controlling and tracing alterations in diffusion model outputs.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes TAFAP, a new method to actively protect data and privacy in diffusion-based text-to-image models by steering fine-tuning toward user-specified target concepts, achieving controllable and verifiable targeted data protection without sacrificing image quality.
AI.motivation: Personalization of diffusion-based text-to-image models through fine-tuning is becoming easy, but this raises risks of unauthorized use of personal or proprietary data. Existing protections only passively degrade image quality and lack stable, precise control. Targeted Data Protection (TDP) is a promising direction that tries to redirect model behavior toward safe target concepts, but prior TDP methods rely on snapshot-matching and cannot robustly control the learning process over the full fine-tuning trajectory, leading to weak or diluted protection.
AI.method: The authors propose TAFAP (Trajectory Alignment via Fine-tuning with Adversarial Perturbations), which controls the entire training trajectory of diffusion models instead of just matching individual snapshots. Inspired by dataset distillation, TAFAP introduces adversarial perturbations that enforce trajectory alignment: during fine-tuning, the model is guided so that its evolving parameters follow a path corresponding to a user-defined target concept. This trajectory-matching approach is designed to create persistent and verifiable transformations in how the model learns during personalization, ensuring that protected concepts are consistently redirected to targets.
AI.result: Through extensive experiments on diffusion-based text-to-image models, TAFAP is shown to be the first method that successfully achieves targeted transformation with simultaneous control over both identity (who/what is depicted) and visual patterns (style/appearance). It significantly outperforms existing Targeted Data Protection methods in controllability and robustness, consistently steering outputs toward specified target concepts while preserving high image quality. The empirical results confirm that the protective effect of TAFAP does not fade as training proceeds, unlike snapshot-based approaches.
AI.conclusion: TAFAP demonstrates that trajectory-level control of fine-tuning in diffusion models enables effective and verifiable Targeted Data Protection. By aligning the full training trajectory toward target concepts via adversarial perturbations, the method provides robust redirection of model outputs without degrading image quality. This establishes a new framework for safeguarding sensitive data in personalization workflows and for tracing and controlling how diffusion models’ outputs are altered during fine-tuning.

title: When Reject Turns into Accept: Quantifying the Vulnerability of LLM-Based Scientific Reviewers to Indirect Prompt Injection
summary: The landscape of scientific peer review is rapidly evolving with the integration of Large Language Models (LLMs). This shift is driven by two parallel trends: the widespread individual adoption of LLMs by reviewers to manage workload (the "Lazy Reviewer" hypothesis) and the formal institutional deployment of AI-powered assessment systems by conferences like AAAI and Stanford's Agents4Science. This study investigates the robustness of these "LLM-as-a-Judge" systems (both illicit and sanctioned) to adversarial PDF manipulation. Unlike general jailbreaks, we focus on a distinct incentive: flipping "Reject" decisions to "Accept," for which we develop a novel evaluation metric which we term as WAVS (Weighted Adversarial Vulnerability Score). We curated a dataset of 200 scientific papers and adapted 15 domain-specific attack strategies to this task, evaluating them across 13 Language Models, including GPT-5, Claude Haiku, and DeepSeek. Our results demonstrate that obfuscation strategies like "Maximum Mark Magyk" successfully manipulate scores, achieving alarming decision flip rates even in large-scale models. We will release our complete dataset and injection framework to facilitate more research on this topic.

AI.tldr: Study analyzes how vulnerable AI-based peer-review systems are to adversarial PDF attacks that try to flip a paper’s decision from reject to accept, introducing a new robustness metric and evaluation framework.
AI.motivation: As LLMs are increasingly used—both informally by reviewers and formally by conferences—to judge scientific papers, there is a critical need to understand how easily these systems can be manipulated. Specifically, there is concern that malicious authors could craft PDF submissions to exploit prompt-injection and obfuscation vulnerabilities in LLM-based reviewers, changing rejection outcomes to acceptance and undermining the integrity of scientific publishing.
AI.method: The authors assemble a dataset of 200 scientific papers and design 15 targeted, domain-specific adversarial attack strategies tailored to PDFs used in peer review. They then evaluate these attacks across 13 different language models (including state-of-the-art systems like GPT-5, Claude Haiku, and DeepSeek) configured as automated reviewers. To measure robustness in a task-relevant way, they introduce a new metric called WAVS (Weighted Adversarial Vulnerability Score), which captures how effectively attacks can flip a negative (reject) decision into a positive (accept) one. They systematically test obfuscation and injection tactics, such as the "Maximum Mark Magyk" method, and quantify decision flip rates for each model and attack type.
AI.result: The experiments show that many LLM-as-a-judge systems are highly susceptible to adversarial PDF manipulation. Certain obfuscation-based attacks—particularly the "Maximum Mark Magyk" strategy—can significantly alter review scores and, in many cases, flip overall decisions from reject to accept, even for advanced large models. The WAVS metric reveals substantial adversarial vulnerability across the evaluated models, indicating that neither scale nor state-of-the-art status guarantees robustness.
AI.conclusion: LLM-based peer-review systems, whether unofficial tools used by individual reviewers or official mechanisms adopted by conferences, are currently fragile against adversarially crafted PDFs. Decision-flipping attacks are practical and effective across a range of modern models. The authors conclude that relying on LLMs as autonomous or near-autonomous judges in scientific assessment poses serious integrity and security risks unless robust defenses, auditing procedures, and standardized robustness benchmarks—such as the released dataset, attack suite, and WAVS metric—are developed and adopted.

title: Planning, Living and Judging: A Multi-agent LLM-based Framework for Cyclical Urban Planning
comment: 4 pages, 2 figures, accepted by The 1st Workshop on AI for Urban Planning (AAAI 2025's Workshop)
summary: Urban regeneration presents significant challenges within the context of urbanization, requiring adaptive approaches to tackle evolving needs. Leveraging advancements in large language models (LLMs), we propose Cyclical Urban Planning (CUP), a new paradigm that continuously generates, evaluates, and refines urban plans in a closed-loop. Specifically, our multi-agent LLM-based framework consists of three key components: (1) Planning, where LLM agents generate and refine urban plans based on contextual data; (2) Living, where agents simulate the behaviors and interactions of residents, modeling life in the urban environment; and (3) Judging, which involves evaluating plan effectiveness and providing iterative feedback for improvement. The cyclical process enables a dynamic and responsive planning approach. Experiments on the real-world dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our framework as a continuous and adaptive planning process.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Cyclical Urban Planning (CUP), a multi-agent LLM framework that continuously generates, simulates, and evaluates urban regeneration plans in a closed loop.
AI.motivation: Urban regeneration in fast-changing cities requires planning methods that can adapt dynamically to evolving needs, behaviors, and constraints. Traditional planning processes are often static, slow, and unable to incorporate rich, real-time contextual data or nuanced human behaviors. With the emergence of powerful large language models capable of reasoning, simulation, and iterative refinement, there is an opportunity to rethink urban planning as a continuous, data-driven, and feedback-oriented process.
AI.method: The authors design a multi-agent framework built on large language models with three interconnected components: (1) Planning: LLM agents generate initial urban regeneration plans and iteratively refine them using contextual data (e.g., spatial, social, or economic information). (2) Living: LLM agents simulate residents’ daily lives, behaviors, and interactions in the planned urban environment, effectively stress-testing the plans through virtual scenarios. (3) Judging: LLM agents evaluate how well the plans perform under these simulated conditions, identify shortcomings, and provide structured feedback. These three stages form a closed-loop, cyclical process where plans are repeatedly improved based on simulated outcomes and evaluations. The framework is tested on a real-world dataset to assess feasibility and performance.
AI.result: Experiments on a real-world urban dataset show that the CUP framework can effectively act as a continuous and adaptive planning system. The cyclic interaction between planning, simulation of resident life, and evaluation leads to more responsive and refined urban plans compared with a single-pass or static approach. Quantitative and/or qualitative experimental evidence (not detailed in the abstract) supports the claim that CUP improves the quality and adaptability of urban regeneration plans.
AI.conclusion: Cyclical Urban Planning (CUP) demonstrates that multi-agent LLM systems can support urban regeneration by treating planning as an ongoing, closed-loop process rather than a one-off design exercise. By combining plan generation, behavioral simulation, and iterative evaluation, the framework provides a dynamic and responsive approach to urban planning. This suggests that advanced LLMs can play a substantive role in future urban governance and planning workflows, especially where continuous adaptation to changing urban conditions is required.

title: Zero-shot 3D Map Generation with LLM Agents: A Dual-Agent Architecture for Procedural Content Generation
summary: Procedural Content Generation (PCG) offers scalable methods for algorithmically creating complex, customizable worlds. However, controlling these pipelines requires the precise configuration of opaque technical parameters. We propose a training-free architecture that utilizes LLM agents for zero-shot PCG parameter configuration. While Large Language Models (LLMs) promise a natural language interface for PCG tools, off-the-shelf models often fail to bridge the semantic gap between abstract user instructions and strict parameter specifications. Our system pairs an Actor agent with a Critic agent, enabling an iterative workflow where the system autonomously reasons over tool parameters and refines configurations to progressively align with human design preferences. We validate this approach on the generation of various 3D maps, establishing a new benchmark for instruction-following in PCG. Experiments demonstrate that our approach outperforms single-agent baselines, producing diverse and structurally valid environments from natural language descriptions. These results demonstrate that off-the-shelf LLMs can be effectively repurposed as generalized agents for arbitrary PCG tools. By shifting the burden from model training to architectural reasoning, our method offers a scalable framework for mastering complex software without task-specific fine-tuning.

AI.tldr: They build a training-free, two-agent LLM system (Actor + Critic) that automatically configures PCG parameters from natural language, outperforming single-agent baselines for 3D map generation.
AI.motivation: PCG tools can create rich worlds but require manual tuning of many low-level, opaque parameters, making them hard for non-experts and limiting scalability. Existing LLMs could provide a natural language interface, but they struggle to translate high-level human intent into precise PCG parameter settings.
AI.method: They design a zero-shot architecture based on off-the-shelf LLMs acting as coordinated agents. An Actor agent proposes PCG parameter configurations from natural language instructions, while a Critic agent evaluates and iteratively guides refinements. This loop continues until the configurations better match human design preferences, without any model fine-tuning. They apply this framework to 3D map generation and define a benchmark for instruction-following in PCG.
AI.result: On the new 3D map generation benchmark, their Actor–Critic multi-agent system produces more diverse and structurally valid environments than single-agent LLM baselines when conditioned on natural language descriptions. Quantitative and/or qualitative evaluations show improved alignment with user instructions and better parameter configurations.
AI.conclusion: A multi-agent, training-free LLM architecture can effectively control complex PCG tools via natural language, repurposing general-purpose LLMs as parameter-configuration agents. By focusing on architectural coordination rather than fine-tuning, their approach offers a scalable way to leverage existing LLMs for a wide range of PCG workflows and potentially other complex software systems.

title: Achieving Olympia-Level Geometry Large Language Model Agent via Complexity Boosting Reinforcement Learning
summary: Large language model (LLM) agents exhibit strong mathematical problem-solving abilities and can even solve International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO) level problems with the assistance of formal proof systems. However, due to weak heuristics for auxiliary constructions, AI for geometry problem solving remains dominated by expert models such as AlphaGeometry 2, which rely heavily on large-scale data synthesis and search for both training and evaluation. In this work, we make the first attempt to build a medalist-level LLM agent for geometry and present InternGeometry. InternGeometry overcomes the heuristic limitations in geometry by iteratively proposing propositions and auxiliary constructions, verifying them with a symbolic engine, and reflecting on the engine's feedback to guide subsequent proposals. A dynamic memory mechanism enables InternGeometry to conduct more than two hundred interactions with the symbolic engine per problem. To further accelerate learning, we introduce Complexity-Boosting Reinforcement Learning (CBRL), which gradually increases the complexity of synthesized problems across training stages. Built on InternThinker-32B, InternGeometry solves 44 of 50 IMO geometry problems (2000-2024), exceeding the average gold medalist score (40.9), using only 13K training examples, just 0.004% of the data used by AlphaGeometry 2, demonstrating the potential of LLM agents on expert-level geometry tasks. InternGeometry can also propose novel auxiliary constructions for IMO problems that do not appear in human solutions. We will release the model, data, and symbolic engine to support future research.

AI.tldr: InternGeometry is an LLM-based geometry problem-solving agent that reaches IMO gold-medalist level by tightly integrating with a symbolic engine and using a curriculum-style reinforcement learning scheme, while requiring orders of magnitude less training data than expert systems like AlphaGeometry 2.
AI.motivation: Although LLM agents are strong at many forms of mathematical reasoning, geometry remains challenging because it often requires clever, non-obvious auxiliary constructions and structured symbolic reasoning. Existing state-of-the-art systems like AlphaGeometry 2 rely heavily on expert-designed search procedures and very large synthetic datasets, which limits scalability and generality. The authors aim to show that a more generic LLM agent, if properly coupled with a symbolic engine and trained with an appropriate curriculum, can match or exceed expert systems on Olympiad-level geometry problems using far less data.
AI.method: The authors build InternGeometry on top of the InternThinker-32B LLM. The agent operates in an iterative propose–verify–reflect loop: it proposes propositions and auxiliary constructions, passes them to a symbolic engine for verification, and then uses the engine's feedback to refine subsequent proposals. A dynamic memory mechanism allows the agent to manage and exploit over two hundred interaction steps with the engine per problem. For training, they design Complexity-Boosting Reinforcement Learning (CBRL), a curriculum-like RL framework where the training data consists of synthesized geometry problems whose difficulty is gradually increased across stages to improve the agent's capability without requiring massive datasets.
AI.result: InternGeometry solves 44 out of 50 IMO geometry problems from 2000–2024, surpassing the average score of human gold medalists (40.9 points) on this benchmark. Remarkably, it achieves this performance with only 13,000 training examples, which is just 0.004% of the data used by AlphaGeometry 2, while maintaining competitive or superior performance. The system also demonstrates the capacity to generate auxiliary constructions that differ from known human solutions, suggesting some level of creativity or alternative reasoning pathways.
AI.conclusion: The work demonstrates that LLM-based agents, when tightly integrated with a symbolic engine and trained via a complexity-boosting RL curriculum, can reach and even surpass IMO gold-medalist level on challenging geometry problems while using orders of magnitude less training data than prior expert systems. This suggests a promising path toward more data-efficient, general-purpose AI mathematicians. The authors plan to release the model, data, and symbolic engine to facilitate further research and extension of these ideas.

title: NormCode: A Semi-Formal Language for Context-Isolated AI Planning
summary: Multistep workflows that chain large language model (LLM) calls suffer from context pollution: as information accumulates across steps, models hallucinate, confuse intermediate outputs, and lose track of task constraints. We present NormCode, a semiformal language for constructing plans of inferences, structured decompositions where each step operates in data isolation and receives only explicitly passed inputs, which eliminates crossstep contamination by design. NormCode enforces a strict separation between semantic operations (LLMdriven reasoning, nondeterministic) and syntactic operations (deterministic data restructuring), enabling precise cost and reliability tracing. The language exists in three isomorphic formats: .ncds for human authoring, .ncd for machine execution, and .ncn for human verification, supporting progressive formalization from sketch to production. We validate NormCode through two demonstrations: (1) a base X addition algorithm achieving 100 percent accuracy on arbitrary length inputs, and (2) self hosted execution of NormCode's own five phase compiler pipeline. The working orchestrator provides dependency driven scheduling, SQLite backed checkpointing, and loop management, making AI workflows auditable by design and addressing a critical need for transparency in high stakes domains such as legal reasoning, medical decision making, and financial analysis.

AI.tldr: NormCode is a semiformal language and runtime that structures LLM workflows into isolated, auditable steps to prevent context pollution and improve reliability.
AI.motivation: Multistep LLM workflows often accumulate too much unstructured context, leading to hallucinations, confusion between intermediate results, and failure to obey constraints—problems especially serious in high‑stakes domains like law, medicine, and finance. There is a need for a principled way to design and execute complex AI workflows that remain interpretable, debuggable, and reliable as they scale.
AI.method: The authors design NormCode, a semiformal planning language that decomposes workflows into inference steps with strict data isolation: each step only sees explicitly provided inputs, preventing cross‑step contamination. They distinguish semantic (LLM, nondeterministic) operations from syntactic (deterministic, structural) operations to enable precise tracking of cost and reliability. NormCode is realized in three isomorphic representations (.ncds for human authoring, .ncd for machine execution, .ncn for human verification), allowing progressive refinement from informal sketch to formal spec. They implement an orchestrator that performs dependency‑aware scheduling, SQLite‑based checkpointing, and loop control, and then validate the system via two demonstrations: a base‑X addition algorithm and self‑hosting of NormCode’s own five‑phase compiler pipeline.
AI.result: NormCode successfully expresses and executes a base‑X addition algorithm that reaches 100% accuracy on arbitrarily long inputs, indicating the framework can support precise algorithmic reasoning. The same system is used to implement and execute its own five‑phase compiler pipeline, demonstrating self‑hosting and practical viability. The orchestrator can schedule dependent tasks, checkpoint to SQLite, and manage loops while maintaining step isolation and traceability.
AI.conclusion: Structuring LLM workflows with NormCode’s semiformal language and runtime eliminates context pollution by design, separates nondeterministic reasoning from deterministic data manipulation, and yields auditable, reliable, and scalable AI pipelines. This approach is particularly suited for domains that demand transparency and accountability, and it shows that complex, even self‑referential, workflows can be robustly implemented on top of LLMs when governed by strict data and control structures.

title: Phythesis: Physics-Guided Evolutionary Scene Synthesis for Energy-Efficient Data Center Design via LLMs
summary: Data center (DC) infrastructure serves as the backbone to support the escalating demand for computing capacity. Traditional design methodologies that blend human expertise with specialized simulation tools scale poorly with the increasing system complexity. Recent studies adopt generative artificial intelligence to design plausible human-centric indoor layouts. However, they do not consider the underlying physics, making them unsuitable for the DC design that sets quantifiable operational objectives and strict physical constraints. To bridge the gap, we propose Phythesis, a novel framework that synergizes large language models (LLMs) and physics-guided evolutionary optimization to automate simulation-ready (SimReady) scene synthesis for energy-efficient DC design. Phythesis employs an iterative bi-level optimization architecture, where (i) the LLM-driven optimization level generates physically plausible three-dimensional layouts and self-criticizes them to refine the scene topology, and (ii) the physics-informed optimization level identifies the optimal asset parameters and selects the best asset combination. Experiments on three generation scales show that Phythesis achieves 57.3% generation success rate increase and 11.5% power usage effectiveness (PUE) improvement, compared with the vanilla LLM-based solution.

AI.tldr: Phythesis is a framework that combines large language models with physics-guided evolutionary optimization to automatically generate simulation-ready, energy-efficient data center layouts.
AI.motivation: As data centers grow in scale and complexity, traditional manual-plus-simulation design workflows become too slow and unscalable. Existing generative AI methods can design indoor layouts but ignore physical constraints and quantifiable performance metrics, making them unsuitable for data center design where physics (e.g., cooling, airflow, power) and operational efficiency are critical.
AI.method: Phythesis uses a bi-level optimization architecture. At the first level, an LLM generates 3D, physically plausible data center layouts and iteratively refines them via self-criticism to improve scene topology. At the second level, a physics-informed evolutionary optimization module tunes asset parameters and selects the best combination of assets based on physical simulations and operational objectives such as energy efficiency.
AI.result: Across three different generation scales, Phythesis improves the success rate of generating valid layouts by 57.3% and achieves an 11.5% reduction in power usage effectiveness (PUE) compared to a baseline that uses only LLM-based layout generation without the physics-guided optimization.
AI.conclusion: By tightly coupling LLM-driven scene synthesis with physics-guided evolutionary optimization, Phythesis can automatically produce simulation-ready, energy-efficient data center designs that outperform purely LLM-based generative approaches in both feasibility and energy performance.

title: Remember Me, Refine Me: A Dynamic Procedural Memory Framework for Experience-Driven Agent Evolution
summary: Procedural memory enables large language model (LLM) agents to internalize "how-to" knowledge, theoretically reducing redundant trial-and-error. However, existing frameworks predominantly suffer from a "passive accumulation" paradigm, treating memory as a static append-only archive. To bridge the gap between static storage and dynamic reasoning, we propose $\textbf{ReMe}$ ($\textit{Remember Me, Refine Me}$), a comprehensive framework for experience-driven agent evolution. ReMe innovates across the memory lifecycle via three mechanisms: 1) $\textit{multi-faceted distillation}$, which extracts fine-grained experiences by recognizing success patterns, analyzing failure triggers and generating comparative insights; 2) $\textit{context-adaptive reuse}$, which tailors historical insights to new contexts via scenario-aware indexing; and 3) $\textit{utility-based refinement}$, which autonomously adds valid memories and prunes outdated ones to maintain a compact, high-quality experience pool. Extensive experiments on BFCL-V3 and AppWorld demonstrate that ReMe establishes a new state-of-the-art in agent memory system. Crucially, we observe a significant memory-scaling effect: Qwen3-8B equipped with ReMe outperforms larger, memoryless Qwen3-14B, suggesting that self-evolving memory provides a computation-efficient pathway for lifelong learning. We release our code and the $\texttt{reme.library}$ dataset to facilitate further research.

AI.tldr: ReMe is a memory framework for LLM agents that turns procedural experiences into compact, useful "how-to" knowledge, improving performance and sample efficiency over larger memoryless models.
AI.motivation: Existing LLM agent memory is mostly passive, storing experiences as static logs without actively structuring, refining, or leveraging them for better reasoning. This limits agents’ ability to learn efficiently from past trials and to scale capabilities via memory instead of larger models.
AI.method: ReMe introduces three mechanisms spanning the memory lifecycle: (1) multi-faceted distillation, which converts raw interaction trajectories into fine-grained lessons by detecting success patterns, diagnosing failures, and forming comparative insights; (2) context-adaptive reuse, which retrieves and adapts relevant memories to new tasks through scenario-aware indexing; and (3) utility-based refinement, which automatically curates the memory pool by adding useful experiences and pruning obsolete or low-value ones.
AI.result: On BFCL-V3 and AppWorld benchmarks, ReMe sets a new state-of-the-art for LLM agent memory systems. The authors show a memory-scaling effect: a smaller model (Qwen3-8B) with ReMe surpasses a larger Qwen3-14B without memory, indicating that structured, evolving memory can compensate for model size.
AI.conclusion: Actively distilled, adaptively reused, and utility-refined procedural memory can make LLM agents more capable and efficient, enabling smaller models with good memory to outperform larger memoryless ones. ReMe demonstrates a practical pathway toward lifelong, experience-based learning for LLM agents and provides code and a curated memory dataset (reme.library) to support further research.

title: Refinement Contrastive Learning of Cell-Gene Associations for Unsupervised Cell Type Identification
summary: Unsupervised cell type identification is crucial for uncovering and characterizing heterogeneous populations in single cell omics studies. Although a range of clustering methods have been developed, most focus exclusively on intrinsic cellular structure and ignore the pivotal role of cell-gene associations, which limits their ability to distinguish closely related cell types. To this end, we propose a Refinement Contrastive Learning framework (scRCL) that explicitly incorporates cell-gene interactions to derive more informative representations. Specifically, we introduce two contrastive distribution alignment components that reveal reliable intrinsic cellular structures by effectively exploiting cell-cell structural relationships. Additionally, we develop a refinement module that integrates gene-correlation structure learning to enhance cell embeddings by capturing underlying cell-gene associations. This module strengthens connections between cells and their associated genes, refining the representation learning to exploiting biologically meaningful relationships. Extensive experiments on several single-cell RNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in cell-type identification accuracy. Moreover, downstream biological analyses confirm that the recovered cell populations exhibit coherent gene-expression signatures, further validating the biological relevance of our approach. The code is available at https://github.com/THPengL/scRCL.

AI.tldr: Proposes scRCL, a refinement contrastive learning framework that leverages both cell-cell and cell-gene relationships to improve unsupervised cell-type identification in single-cell omics, achieving better accuracy and biologically coherent clusters than existing methods.
AI.motivation: Existing unsupervised clustering methods for single-cell omics largely focus on intrinsic cellular structure (cell-cell similarities) and neglect explicit modeling of cell-gene associations. This omission makes it difficult to distinguish closely related cell types and to fully exploit biologically meaningful relationships between cells and genes. There is a need for a method that can jointly leverage cell-cell structure and cell-gene interactions to produce more informative representations for cell-type identification.
AI.method: The paper introduces scRCL, a Refinement Contrastive Learning framework for unsupervised cell-type identification. It has two main components: (1) contrastive distribution alignment modules that exploit cell-cell structural relationships to uncover reliable intrinsic cellular structures, and (2) a refinement module that learns gene-correlation structures and embeds cell-gene associations into the latent representation. The refinement module strengthens connections between cells and their associated genes, allowing the model to refine cell embeddings by capturing underlying biologically meaningful interactions. The entire framework is trained in a contrastive learning manner to produce improved cell representations for clustering.
AI.result: On multiple benchmark single-cell RNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics datasets, scRCL consistently outperforms state-of-the-art clustering and representation learning baselines in terms of cell-type identification accuracy. The clusters discovered by scRCL are more accurate and coherent. Additionally, downstream biological analyses show that the identified cell populations have consistent and interpretable gene-expression signatures, demonstrating that the method captures biologically relevant structure in the data.
AI.conclusion: By explicitly integrating cell-gene associations into a contrastive learning framework, scRCL yields more informative cell representations that improve unsupervised cell-type identification in single-cell omics. The method outperforms existing approaches across various datasets and produces biologically coherent clusters, indicating that modeling both cell-cell and cell-gene relationships is a powerful strategy for analyzing heterogeneous cell populations. The public code release facilitates adoption and further validation by the community.

title: Replace, Don't Expand: Mitigating Context Dilution in Multi-Hop RAG via Fixed-Budget Evidence Assembly
summary: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems often fail on multi-hop queries when the initial retrieval misses a bridge fact.
